The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) will respond to any questions relating to the portfolio of Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) will respond to any questions on defence matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to remarks made yesterday by Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, former Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and at present a member of the Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: I'd put whatever money I own in fixed-term investments. If people can get 14 or 15 per cent from a fixed term investment, if you do your sums right, over the years that's much better than the average company can possibly do.

Does the Treasurer agree with Mr Fitzgibbon's widely held assessment of Australia's investment climate that the after-tax real rate of return in Australia remains very low and insufficient relative to the return available on low risk financial assets to justify the decision to undertake productive investment projects? In view of Mr Fitzgibbon's assessment, does the Treasurer still stand by his prediction on Budget night that the Budget forecast for business fixed investment will be exceeded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a couple of points. First, Mr Fitzgibbon is not a member of EPAC. The second thing is that if Mr Fitzgibbon were an investment whiz he probably would be worth a lot more than he is today.
—Is he still a member of the Reserve Bank Board?

—Yes, he is a member of the Reserve Bank of Australia Board-a very valued and valuable member, I might add. There is a very great distinction, though, between being a member of the Reserve Bank and casting one's view about public policy and the application of public policy and providing investment advice to the rest of the nation.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make this position clear: I said yesterday that one really had to wonder how, with terms of trade far more advantageous than this Government has enjoyed, the former Government could have run Australia into the first negative growth in 30 years without an external depression in prices. This Government has had an enormous external depression in prices; yet, without any mining boom, we have had economic growth rates at about 14 to 15 per cent cumulative over three years. We have seen the profit share substantially restored from the appallingly low levels that the coalition ran it to in the 1970s, the consequence of which has seen buoyancy in the Australian stock exchanges for well over three years now-of course, in recent times the stock exchange index record was broken twice in a week-and the growth of profitability of many large corporations greatly exceeding that of the fixed rate market. I just do not think that many of our entrepreneurs would accept the view that they should not have been out there using the opportunities of this growth economy, that they should have been putting their money into fixed rate securities. Some people nevertheless may feel secure and comfortable with the fixed rate market. That is quite a reasonable judgment on their part. If the honourable gentleman's question is implying that three years of wage restraint, a greater adjustment in relative wages in this country than in any country we trade with, and a restoration of the profit share in some way reflect upon this Government's capacity to get the factor shares right when the Opposition ran Australian business and its profitability into the ground, one wonders how it can have so much hide to address such a question to this Government when its own performance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Well, here is the world's champion giggler who ran Australian business into the ground. He presided over more bankruptcies than any Treasurer in history. He had the leaders of major business, who had voted Liberal all their lives and been supporters of the coalition, saying to any of us in the Australian Labor Party who would listen in 1982-83: `The quicker this mob goes the better we will have a chance of restoring our profits'. That record of decimating Australian business, wiping out manufacturing and squandering a mineral boom to give us negative growth for the first time in 30 years and to give us the greatest depression since the Great Depression, although terms of trade were massively more advantageous then than those we enjoy now, takes a special feat of incompetence. One has to rise to the level of a performing art in incompetence to produce negative growth after a mining boom with terms of trade so advantageous.

ANSWER.PARA: How could the Opposition induce a domestic recession here with the advantageous terms of trade it had and a mining boom to boot? How could it ask us a question about its economic credentials after doubling the unemployment rate over 18 months, driving the inflation rate to double digits, smashing the profit share and giving us massive wage growth in a wages explosion in 1981? Yet the Opposition has some question about the fixed rate market and the level of profitability. I will let the stock market provide the Opposition with the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister tell the House how the Australia Card fits in with the Government's ongoing program of tax reform? What will the chief benefits be to the Australian people of the Australia Card?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Chisholm for her question. There is no doubt that the Australia Card program is the most effective possible weapon against tax evasion and social security fraud. When fully operational the Australia Card is estimated to cost $55m a year but to generate total savings of $932m a year. In other words, in a full year of operation there will be a net saving from the Australia Card of $877m. That means-and I say this particularly to the honourable member-that by 1995-96 the Australia Card will have saved $4.7 billion which otherwise would have been lost in tax evasion and welfare fraud. Given those facts, there is absolutely no wonder that the concept of the Australia Card has very widespread community support, as is evidenced in the most recent polls.

ANSWER.PARA: The tax file number concept as an alternative simply does not have anywhere near the same effectiveness as the Australia Card. That is more open to forgery and fraud. It would save only an estimated $276m a year, or less than one-third of the savings of the Australia Card, which would mean cumulatively that by 1995-96 a tax file system would have missed out on savings of the order of $3 billion compared to the Australia Card.

Given the enormous and fairly constant noise that members of the Opposition make about welfare fraud, I suppose that we on this side of the House are entitled to look forward to their support for the introduction of the Australia Card. In that respect it is well to remember the comments that have been made by some people in the Opposition. I will refer briefly to some of them. On the Sunday program on 15 September last year the Leader of the Opposition, when asked about the Australia Card, said:
. . . I think there is some merit in giving it favourable consideration.

On 5 June last year the Deputy Leader of the National Party, who in these areas is pretty consistent with sensible and honest statements-I am sorry to embarrass him, but he is-also made supportive comments. On 8 June last year the honourable member for Richmond, now the shadow Social Security Minister, said-and it is very interesting--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is still chasing his tail.
—He will have to chase this statement pretty hard, too, unless he comes down on the right side. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I think honest taxpayers are sick and tired of the restrictions which tax and social security fraud impose upon their own liberties. With the Government's White Paper on tax reform recommending the introduction of ID cards, there is now broad bipartisan support for this measure.
He concluded:
It should therefore be implemented.
Full marks to the honourable member. We will watch very closely to see how he votes when the legislation comes before the House. The shadow Treasurer said on 3 December last year:

Social security cheats are robbing not only the unfortunate taxpayers whose hard-earned money is being paid out to thieves, but also on genuine welfare beneficiaries who deserve every scrap of assistance they can get . . . It is time the Government demonstrated at least equal concern over the welfare cheats scandal to that shown over tax evasion and avoidance.

That time has come with the introduction into the House tomorrow of the Australia Card Bill. That Bill contains the most comprehensive measures imaginable for the protection of civil liberties. In answer to the question and to members of this House I simply say that this Government is fully determined to protect the rights and privacy of Australians. But we are at least equally determined to crack down on tax evaders and welfare cheats. The Opposition will have the chance to do that when this legislation is introduced into this House. If it chooses not to support the Australia Card, two things will have been demonstrated: Firstly, the Opposition will continue in its role in the community as the friend of the tax cheats and avoiders and its blatant hypocrisy on social security fraud will have been fully revealed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES ACT: SECONDARY BOYCOTT PROVISIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the secondary boycott provisions contained in sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act which have proved to be the most effective sanction against the predatory and destructive use of excessive union power. Will the Prime Minister give the Parliament a categorical assurance that the Government will take no action to abolish, water down or tamper in any way with those secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say two or three things which are relevant to the question quite properly asked by the Leader of the Opposition. Firstly, as is well known, the Government, through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, is looking at the whole question of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Within that Act the Minister is considering the matter of sanctions. It would be premature for me to prejudge the recommendations that the Minister will bring to the Cabinet on this issue. It will not have escaped the notice of the Leader of the Opposition that my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has publicly commented on this question and has given an indication of the thinking that he will bring to the Government about the role of some form of sanctions within the conciliation and arbitration legislation. I repeat: `Within the conciliation and arbitration legislation'. When the Minister has brought forward those proposals, they will be considered by the Cabinet and will be fully explained to both this House and the people of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I make a general observation about the question of industrial relations in this country. As my colleague the Treasurer said in answer to the first question, it ill becomes the people on the other side of the House to ask questions in this area, because it had a most pathetic record. The Opposition had seven and a half years in which it was open to it to use whatever provisions it sought to use, inside or outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, to bring about an appropriate system of industrial relations. The facts are quite clear. Under this Government the monthly average of days lost due to industrial disputes since April 1983 is 116,000. That figure, which is the monthly average since April 1983, compares with a figure of 248,400 in the period of the conservative government. In other words, days lost in this country due to industrial disputes more than halved under this Government.

This country had the opportunity of seeing the Opposition's program, its philosophy, and its ideology in operation for seven and a half years and it has had the opportunity of seeing this Government's policies in operation. The effects are dramatically clear: Fewer than half the number of industrial disputes. That is because we are much more likely to get the removal of the conditions which bring about industrial disputation if we follow a policy of consultation and co-operation, which is the hallmark of this Government, rather than the policy of confrontation which characterised the other mob. That is one of the reasons-and it coincides with what my colleague the Treasurer said-why the business community tried the mob opposite, saw it in operation for seven and a half years, and found it wanting. The business community listened to all the blustering and rhetoric about reducing industrial disputes. All the Opposition succeeded in doing was creating more than double the level of industrial disputes that have occurred under the policy and approach of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services and concerns the Australian made campaign. Is there scope for local councils to play a role in the development of the Australian made campaign? If so, what measures are being taken by the Minister to give effect to the campaign in the local government area?

—I am aware of the role the honourable member has played in encouraging local government to support the campaign that was started by the Prime Minister. I have already written to every local government authority in Australia and to the Australian Council of Local Government Associations to alert them to the positive aspects for our balance of trade and particularly for employment if they support the Australian made campaign. I have sought their co-operation and their support. Local government has a significant role to play because the services it provides require the spending of something in the order of $4 billion yearly. In addition, the leaders of local government, particularly in rural and provincial areas, are opinion makers. I am quite sure that they can talk to local firms and to consumers generally in support of this campaign. Local government has played a major role in the economic recovery of this country, particularly since 1983, when our Government set out to revive the economy. We have created 650,000 jobs, and to a great extent local government has participated in that job creation with the support and co-operation of the Federal Government. I am quite sure that local government will play a major role in this program to support Australian made products.

—I refer the Treasurer to the many small business proprietors, farmers and journalists, amongst others, who use a room in their homes at night and on weekends either to write up their books or otherwise attend to their business affairs. Is it intended that the capital gains tax will apply to the family home in those circumstances? Will the Treasurer request the Commissioner of Taxation to issue a ruling providing guidelines on how he will exercise the discretion given to him in calculating the tax in these circumstances?

—I think that is about the third time the honourable member has asked me that question. I will refer the question to the Commissioner, as he requests, but I should imagine that in making a judgment about that property one of the issues would be whether the people were claiming deductions-that is, using it as a business premise and stating that it was a business premise by claiming deductions for it. Obviously that would be material to some assessment that the Commissioner may make.
—Can the Special Minister of State advise the House whether gifts to political parties used for the funding of market research and opinion surveys are required to be disclosed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I thank the honourable member for his question.
—I raise a point of order. That question is seeking of the Special Minister of State an opinion as to the operation of a law. It clearly must be that and, therefore, is out of order.
—The Australian Electoral Commission has given guidelines on it, which honourable members may not be aware of, Madam Speaker. I am going to make them aware.
—Please proceed.

—The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 allows gifts to parties which are made on the condition that they be used for a purpose other than a purpose related to an election, and which are so used, not to be disclosed. The Australian Electoral Commission has provided guidelines as to the purposes for which a gift designated for a non-Commonwealth election purpose might be put without making the gift disclosable. The Commission includes research, opinion polls and critical issue surveys as falling within non-election purposes, provided that the polls or surveys do not relate to the election.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly this is something of a grey area. Some would argue that research by a political party is inevitably related to the next election, otherwise why would it be done. This is a matter which the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform may well address. I think we saw a classic example of the grey area last Friday when we had the rather humiliating spectacle of the Director of the Liberal Party of Australia running around the Press gallery with the latest Liberal Party survey on the state of politics in Australia. The Director, Tony Eggleton, is quite a professional in these areas. He has been in that position for a long time and obviously the Liberal Party is very satisfied with his services. However, I understand that he gave us only half the results. I wondered why he did not give us the other half and then someone told me what the other half was. I might say to the honourable member for Denison, the honourable member for Farrer, the honourable member for Boothby and a couple of others that there is some good news for them because the survey found that there is very little recognition of the people who serve on the front bench. The Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party has about as much recognition in Australian politics as the secretary of the Mongolian pigeon club, so he is not offering us any threat.

It is also interesting to note in that survey that the leading figure in Liberal Party politics in this House, the honourable member for Bennelong, is not looked upon favourably as a future Prime Minister of this country. I do not know why the Director of the Liberal Party did not give us this news. I do not know why the Director of the Liberal Party did not inform us, when those people were polled, of the attitude of the people towards the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Kooyong. I do not know whether the honourable member for Kooyong is still taken into confidence around at Liberal Party headquarters, but he looks satisfied, does he not? He looks happy with developments. All I suggest is that, whilst the Joint Committee may look at this grey area, hopefully the next time the Director of the Liberal Party drops his notes around the Press gallery to give us all the doom and gloom-I do not suspect that is going to last for very long-he should tell us about the other half of the survey, just to drum up a bit of enthusiasm amongst the Liberal and National parties, because it was good news for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the report by the social security review unit located in the Department of Social Security entitled: `Income support for families with children'. Is it a fact that the report draws attention to the relative disadvantage of Australian families with dependent children? Is it also a fact that even if the second round of promised tax cuts goes ahead in July 1987 a family with dependent children on average annual earnings will face a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent and an average tax rate of 20.5 per cent, whilst the same family faced a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent and an average tax rate of 17 1/2 per cent when his Government came to power in March 1983 and that, furthermore, an additional tax cut of $15 a week would be required for that family to restore it to the position it enjoyed in March 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes the release of the issues paper on family assistance by the social security review. I want to emphasise that the purpose of the paper is not to put forward any formal recommendations about family assistance; what it will do is form the basis of community consultations. For that reason it canvasses broad ranges of approach to family assistance with the purpose of generating very wide discussion on these issues in the community. The Government will consult with all interested groups and parties on the important issues raised in the paper and following those consultations the Government will then consider what is the appropriate course of action in the light of those consultations.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that the Leader of the Opposition attached to his question figures on average tax rates for representative people. These are the facts: Prior to the income tax cuts in November 1982 a person on average weekly earnings faced an average tax rate of 23.1 per cent. The tax cuts of 1982 reduced that rate to 20.9 per cent. Following the income tax cuts in November 1984 the average tax rate faced by a person on average weekly earnings fell to 19.9 per cent, and in December of this year further reductions in the marginal tax rates will reduce that average tax rate to 19.7 per cent. So, as I have said before, we have no reason to walk away from the discussion on the outcome of tax administration under this Government as compared with under our predecessor and, I repeat, in the period between now and the next election the Leader of the Opposition may rest assured that we will make the question of the levels of tax and the administration of tax a fundamental issue in the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations seen comments by the Opposition that the Australian traineeship scheme is a failure and that the tax burden is discouraging both employers and young people from taking up traineeships? Can the Minister inform the House of the current progress in implementing the Australian traineeship scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the House that the traineeship system is not a failure and indeed that it is now coming on stream quite strongly. I am aware of the Press statement issued by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on the weekend regarding traineeships in which he alleged that they were a failure. I must say that even for him the statement contained an amazing amount of misinformation. Firstly, he said that the number of traineeships in place on 10 October was 2,449. This was almost 600 less than the actual number in place at that time-3,030. There are commitments by employers for 4,850 traineeships. So we can see that the actual figures are well in advance of those suggested by the honourable member. He also said that the alleged failure to develop traineeships in the private sector was particularly a factor. There are private sector commitments for almost 1,500 traineeships. Recruitments are now occurring in the private sector in the retail industry, the office-clerical area, the furniture removal area and the hospitality and tourism area. Today I attended a launching of traineeships in the food and beverage area in the Australian Capital Territory, most of which were in the private sector. However, two traineeships are to be under the auspices of the Joint House Department in this place. So honourable members will have a chance to observe traineeships in action. Since 10 October the number of traineeship commencements has increased by 130.

ANSWER.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also alleged that the recent ruling of the Commissioner of Taxation would mean that the $1,000 Government grant to employers of trainees to offset on the job training costs would be taxed at full company tax rates. He is wrong in saying that. It is true that on the face of it the grants are assessable income, but tax is not paid unless the money is not spent for the purposes for which it is provided; that is, to cover the costs of training. Otherwise there is no tax. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also alleged that the off the job training grant for training institutions may also be taxed. If the money is paid to technical and further education colleges, which in most cases will be the off the job training institution, there is, of course, no tax because TAFE institutions are exempt anyway. If it is paid to an industry training centre it may be exempt if the centre is an exempt body under section 23 of the tax Act. If it is not an exempt body it is still not taxable if it is spent for the purpose for which it was provided; that is, to cover training costs.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also alleged that the living away from home allowances paid to trainees would be subject to fringe benefits tax. He is wrong again. There is no tax liability under the fringe benefits tax if the money is used for the purpose provided; that is, to offset accommodation costs. So the Press statement by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was, even for him, a remarkable document, full of misinformation. The amazing thing is that at the end of the statement he said that the Opposition supported traineeships. I can only say that it was an incredibly strange way of demonstrating that support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Territories to the occupation of the public area outside Parliament House by left wing demonstrators and remind him of the action taken by his Department in April 1985 against Vietnamese who were peacefully protesting in much the same area. I ask the Minister: In the light of the abuse and intimidation of members of parliament since the Prime Minister's statement yesterday in Question Time, why has he refused to take action? Will the Government now act to stop the use of public facilities such as electricity for as long as these left wing demonstrators deny the right of all Australians to use that area? Finally, is it a fact that the group `Women for Survival', responsible for much of the intimidation, has received a grant of $2,000 under the International Year of Peace program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware whether an IYP grant has been given to Women for Survival, but it is possible. There has been a fairly consistent practice over recent years of demonstrators being allowed to remain for reasonable periods outside Parliament House. Governments have not acted to remove demonstrators forcibly. The Vietnamese the honourable gentleman mentioned were in front of Parliament House for some two weeks, which is rather longer than the present occupants have been there. They left the site after negotiations with my Department and by agreement with my Department subject to our removing items and delivering them to an address provided by the Vietnamese. It was an amicable settlement and was carried out in a way which was agreed by all parties.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst we may not agree with some of the people who protest against the policies of our respective parties, the right to public demonstration exists and should be defended. Public space does not mean space reserved for members of parliament. If some members of parliament feel aggrieved, or if activities take place which are illegal, there are laws and the police are responsible for the administration of those laws. The powers in the Australian Capital Territory which are available to me would only allow me to remove tents and other structures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you remove the tents then?

—They do not allow me to ban an individual on political grounds from occupying public space, be that individual the Leader of the National Party of Australia or a person who is diametrically opposed to him politically. If I may say so, I think there have been faults on both sides in this set of circumstances. I believe that the success or otherwise of a demonstration depends on how the demonstrators behave. Knowing the political perspectives of honourable members opposite, I suggest that they would feel that the purpose for which the demonstration has been mounted is not being well served by the reported behaviour of the demonstrators.
—Can the Minister for Trade inform the House of the effects on Australian exports and the Australian economy of the Queensland Government's rail freight tariff policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the great contribution the honourable member and other members of the special Caucus committee on the coal industry have made to improve arrangements to facilitate the export of coal. As honourable members will know, coal and other minerals and refined metals account for about a quarter of our annual exports and Queensland supplies about a third of that quantity. Indeed, Australia is now the largest exporter of coal in the world. This Government has been trying to free up the arrangements so that the Australian coal industry has the maximum capacity to compete for new markets around the world. In regard to the mining industry and export industries as a whole, there is a case in some circumstances for governments to collect some of the rent involved in those operations, but there is not a case for the imposition of extortionate taxes, particularly at a time when world prices are declining. Over the last five years coal export prices have fallen by 30 per cent in United States dollar terms.

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Government has imposed rail freight charges on the coal industry in Queensland at a rate which is totally out of line with what is being charged by the rest of the world. For instance, if one compares rail freight rates in Queensland with those in Canada-Canada is an important competitor of ours in the coal industry-one will find that Queensland rail freight rates are 4 1/2 times higher than those in Canada. This makes it more difficult for the coal industry in Queensland to compete with other coal suppliers around the world. If one also looks at the way in which these freight rates are charged, one will find that the charge that is made far exceeds the cost of providing the service. Indeed, it has been estimated that it would take only half the freight rate to cover the cost of freighting the coal from the mines to the port.

The worst thing about this tax is that it is totally indiscriminate. It makes no distinction between low cost mines, of which there are many in Queensland, and high cost mines, of which there are few in Queensland. The Utah Development Co. estimates that, of the $130m in freight charges that it paid to transport coal from its central Queensland mines in the latter half of 1985, the actual cost of providing that freight service was only $40m. So, for one of the largest companies exporting coal from Queensland, over 70 per cent of the amount charged by the Queensland Government was profit to that Government. Such a rich source of revenue has rail freight revenue become for the Queensland Government that it now represents 15 per cent of the total amount of revenue collected by it. One would have thought that, at a time when we were trying to improve Australia's export performance, when the Commonwealth Government was doing all in its power to get fiscal policy right--

TALK.START.PARA: —Get rid of the fringe benefits tax.

—Of course, the irrelevant shadow Minister makes a point about the fringe benefits tax. That does not discriminate between exporting and non-exporting companies, and nor should it. It is a question of quite proper tax policy, which is being introduced, to ensure that everybody who is remunerated in whatever form is taxed in the same way. One would have thought that a time when we were trying to increase our export revenue and a time when we were trying to give our exporters the greatest capacity to export was precisely the wrong time for Queensland to be exploiting some of our most successful exporters.

—No, I will not, because the advice of the National Farmers Federation is wrong.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What grounds exist for optimism concerning the course of economic activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always believe in being prepared for questions, not only from the Opposition but also from the honourable member for Lowe. I guess I can start my answer to the honourable member's question by sharing a view that was expressed on 14 September by Mr Roger Knye, the man behind the Australian desk in the New York rating agency, Moody's Investor Services Inc., in which he said this:

ANSWER.PARA: Moodys thinks the Budget was a brave one. In a rating review we take into account the wisdom or lack thereof of a country's economic managers. One of the positive features of the Australian scene is the intelligent guiding of the ship of state.

I give that as the first reason why I believe that there is sound reason for optimism about the future of the Australian economy. We share the view of Moody's that the economy is in the very best of hands here in Australia, and that is reflected, firstly, in the endorsement of the basic economic strategy that was contained in the Budget. So the fiscal policy, the monetary policy and the emerging wages policy are those which are most likely to enable the Australian business sector to take advantage of the enormous increase in competitiveness that has been created by the devaluation of the recent period, which is of the order of about 35 per cent in trade weighted terms. That, while it has created its own set of problems, while it has meant that some $6 billion has been wiped off our national income, means that Australian manufacturers are able now to compete against imports. Whereas Australian operators were previously sourcing their supplies from overseas, there is now a much greater opportunity for Australian manufacturers to supply. Also, there is a significantly improved opportunity for Australian manufacturers to go into markets overseas which were previously not available to them.

So if we look at all the important elements of economic policy, we believe that they are relevant to enabling Australia to take advantage of this current economic circumstance that has been imposed upon us from outside.

Both I and the Treasurer have pointed out that it is likely that in the rest of 1986 there will still be some adverse figures coming out. The consumer price index for the September quarter will reflect the second devaluation that took place in June and July of this year of the order of 10 to 11 per cent. That, together with certain budgetary decisions, will, we believe, be reflected in a CPI of above average dimensions. In 1986 we will continue to see the flow through of those factors. But we can be certain, I say to the honourable member for Lowe, that as we go into 1987 we will see Australia on a downward inflationary path. Also, we believe that as we go out of 1986 we will have the worst of the balance of payment figures behind us. So all of those basic considerations-fiscal policy, monetary policy, wages policy and industry policy plus the capacity of Australian industry to take advantage of the competitive position with which we have been provided-give me every cause to believe that we should have optimism as we go into 1987.

Let me say finally that the course of Australia's economic destiny is not entirely within our own hands in terms of the decisions and the commitment that we make in this country. We, of course, are therefore watching very closely the economic policy decisions of the United States of America, West Germany and Japan. One of the things that the Treasurer did, and I believe did very forcefully and very effectively on Australia's behalf on his recent visit overseas, was to put to the leaders of the United States, Japan and West Germany in particular the responsibility that they have not only for looking after their own economies but also for playing their part in ensuring that there is a buoyant world economic situation. If we have that in 1987 we are confident that Australia's internal economic policies will lead to growing economic output and employment in a situation of declining inflation. We believe that all of those factors create the environment for a gradual decline in interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister consider the provision of subsidised housing to workers in remote and isolated areas to be blatant and contrived tax avoidance? Can employers in remote and isolated areas be accused of engaging in contrived tax avoidance schemes if their only option is to offer subsidised housing or not have sufficient numbers of workers to man their industries? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member does not seem to be embracing the advice of the honourable member for North Sydney who said that one should not seek advice on these sorts of matters from Ministers. Nevertheless, the Government has made it clear that it is reviewing the question of the impact of the fringe benefits tax. I emphasise to this House that it is doing that within the context of a continuing and unqualified commitment to the principles behind the fringe benefits tax. It is interesting to note that we now have a position where the whole organisation of the Liberal Party, the honourable member's Party, is in favour of the fringe benefits tax. We have had the famous Valder statement, the statement from the Federal President of the Liberal Party, where he said that we are implementing the Opposition's policy. The Federal Secretary of the Party, Mr Eggleton, on Friday, 17 October, said:

ANSWER.PARA: We're defining the taxable fringe benefits, those that are really non cash remuneration, all of these incidental things that have created the terrible problems and anomalies of course should be eliminated.
He was asked:
Are you in favour of the fringe benefits tax in principle?
He said:
In principle . . .

In other words we have the Federal President and the Federal Secretary of the Liberal Party in favour of the tax, and just about the only person in Australia who is now saying that he is against it lock, stock and barrel is the Leader of the Opposition in this place. The people of this country are entitled to ask: Where does the Liberal Party stand? Does it support its Federal President? Does it support its Federal Secretary? Does it support the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia-the rest of the Opposition who say they support the principle-or is the Opposition with this time-serving fellow who is temporarily occupying the position of the Leader of the Opposition, who says that he is against it lock, stock and barrel?

This Government is in favour of the principle of the fringe benefits tax. It is going to bring about a situation where people who were deliberately avoiding their fair payment of taxes are going to be making their contribution. I assure the honourable member that in the review we are undertaking we will look at all the elements-we have had representations on this issue, including in some part from the mining industry, which has made detailed representations to us. I can assure the honourable member that those sorts of things will be taken into account. If there are some changes to be made so that we do not pick up, as I have put it, unintended consequences, they will be made. But they will be made within the framework of a conscientious and principled adherence to bringing into this country a tax which will ensure that those who should be paying their taxes but who were able to avoid it for the whole period the Opposition was in government, will be brought to book.

in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

1. It is unjust for any person to be liable for tax on benefits received by another person.
2. Compliance with FBT will increase administrative costs for all employers including Local, State and Federal government departments.
3. FBT is an inefficient tax, which will require the Tax Office to employ an army of bureaucrats.
4. FBT is inequitable because liability arises regardless of capacity to pay.
5. The FBT laws are extremely complex.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The Tax will:

The Fringe Benefits Tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The Fringe Benefits Tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it, and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

2. The proposed imposition of fees to secondary and TAFE overseas students.
3. The restrictive quota system on the tertiary institutions entry.

The overseas students program is an important education program to promote international goodwill and peace, especially among nations of Asia and Pacific region. The above mentioned policies have adverse effects on the objectives of overseas students program. PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We, the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act as amended in 1985, and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the Government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bills of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes, and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforcable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.
Your petitioners therefore strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Languages
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
(a) Aboriginal and Islander languages, which numbered approximately 260 when Europeans first arrived, are even more seriously endangered-already 145 have become extinct.
(b) English-speaking population expansion and English-speaking mass media expansion threatens the survival of the remaining languages of Australia.

(c) Aboriginal languages reflect an ethos that is truly Australian and unless steps are taken to implement language maintenance, this ethos will be lost not only to Aborigines but to non-Aboriginal Australians, and to the world.
We humbly pray the Government to:

1. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide $300,000 per annum for a guaranteed period of ten years to enable the Aboriginal community of Australia to establish a co-ordinating body to implement steps to prevent the extinction of the remaining languages, and to introduce programmes which will enable these languages to continue into the future for the sake of all Australians. This body will enable us to maximize existing financial, material, and human resources, and is the least expensive way of implementing urgently needed maintenance programmes.
2. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide finance for the establishment of Regional Language Centres-ten are urgently needed-cost $200,000 each.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our Nation.
And your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The introduction of an administrative charge for annual enrolment will restrict access to higher education for a range of disadvantaged groups, particularly women, rural dwellers and some low income earners.
2. Students will be deterred from study because of the probable escalation in the charge in future Budgets, prohibiting students' ability to plan the long term costs of their education.

3. The introduction of an administrative charge is contrary to the education provisions of the ALP/ACTU Accord and ALP policy which states that the party ``will maintain the provision of free tertiary education.''
Your petitioners therefore pray that the annual administrative charge for higher education students not be introduced.
Your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
By drastically cutting E.S.L. funding, you have disadvantaged thousands of Australian children.

Not only will students with limited English face gross educational inequality, but the entire Australian community will feel the wider effect-through the resultant inability of some of its citizens to contribute effectively to Australian society.

On behalf of the children who will be directly affected, and the Australian community generally, we call on you to restore full funding for the general support element of the Commonwealth E.S.L. program.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will: Propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year'' (FIERY) as a vital action to ignite global co-operation for Worldpeace.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing-related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority:
undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public
increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms
increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market
use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.

PETITION.TITLE: Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian republic on or before 1st January 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That in the wake of the Chernobyl reactor disaster, no nuclear reactor can be considered entirely safe.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government close down the Lucas Heights reactors immediately and permanently.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600. We your petitioners, humbly showeth:

That the wildlife species, in this case-the kangaroo, have a right to exist and flourish independently of human needs. For this reason alone we should not regard the kangaroo as a human resource nor contemplate commercial exploitation simply because more offspring are born each generation than can hope to survive.

All Australians have a responsibility to our already declining wildlife.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
1. Ban the exports of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Government has increased wholesale sales tax another 10% under the 1986-87 Budget, resulting in a 20% Sales Tax on wine.

Your petitioners therefore ask that the Government cancels the 20% Sales Tax before it causes a further contraction in our wine industry, with consequential loss of exports, and employment in the wine and tourism and retailing industries which are currently operating in Western Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable taxation deductions;
That the Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is an unwarranted burden on the small business and rural sectors, which will severely affect their long term viability.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government withdraws the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation without delay.

That they request that SBS (channel 28) television be made available to the people of this electorate.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP policy.
