PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully demands that the Federal Government take responsibility for existing and future funding of child care services and that such funding allocation be at such level to ensure the maintenance of quality child care. We further respectfully demand that proper planning of services occur and that the Federal Government enter into formalised agreements with State and Local Governments to achieve this result.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor, Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian atomic energy establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor, Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sutherland Shire respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian atomic energy establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage and high costs inflicted on all Australians by the failure of the Hawke Government's economic policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the Opposition raises in this House the question of the state of the Australian economy. It is a subject we have raised on numerous occasions-in Question Time, in matters of public importance and in various debates over the whole of the time we have been in opposition. We have consistently challenged the economic policies of the Government in this House and elsewhere. It has been claimed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and until recently repeated by the Press Gallery, that the Opposition had not challenged the Government on its economic policies. That is clearly incorrect; it has always been incorrect. The record is there to show it.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet when the Opposition does raise in the Parliament a matter of supreme importance to every Australian, challenges the Treasurer and the Government on their economic policies, who does the Government put up to debate the matter against the Opposition? Is the Treasurer opposite me? Is the Treasurer here to defend his economic policies? No, he is not. Is it even the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the poor hapless Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), the Minister for signing farewell Bob tax reply letters? No, it is not. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) have been sent in here to defend the Government's economic policies. And they do not even agree with the Government's economic policies. The honourable member for Charlton, a member of the Centre Left faction of the Australian Labor Party, challenges the whole central thrust of the Treasurer's policies on trade and imports. He, as chairman of the economic committee of Caucus, has put out statement after statement criticising the Government's main economic proposals. He has put up alternative proposals. The person second in line to defend the Government on this matter is the honourable member for Calwell. If we could go any further left than the honourable member we would be off the planet.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he is off the planet.

—Sometimes the economic policies of the honourable member for Calwell, as the honourable member for Deakin so correctly said, are off the planet. The honourable member for Calwell is on the record, representing the far Left of the Labor Party, putting up a totally different set of economic policies from that of the Government. What a miserable performance on the part of the Government to send a member of the Centre Left back bench and a member of the far Left back bench in here to defend the Government's economic policies. I know why they have been sent in here; it is because the Government's economic policies are indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been in office now for three years and seven months. No longer should Ministers come into the House every Question Time and castigate the previous Government for all of Australia's economic ills. Yet, day after day, in a pathetic performance, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer come in here and tell us about the history of the recession of 1981-82. They do not even tell the history correctly. The Treasurer time and again tries to make the point that he has been bowled over by this extraordinary thing that has happened to him from overseas, a decline in the terms of trade. The Treasurer says that the previous Government did not suffer from a decline in the terms of trade. That may be so but the previous Government was hit by a very deep and broad world recession and by a disastrous drought that covered the whole of Australia for three seasons. Not only that, it was hit by industrial action by metal workers who, according to the Treasurer himself, had dead men around their necks in the metal industries.

The Treasurer, who every day in the House blames the Fraser Government for the recession of 1981-82 and for the wage breakout of 1981-82, went to the Labor National Conference in Hobart and made it quite clear that what happened then on wages was due to industrial action by his mates in the metal trades unions. He said that the metal workers had dead men's jobs around their necks.

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred thousand.

—One hundred thousand of them around their necks. He said that was the reason why the recession bit deeper into the Australian economy than it should have done. Let us nail this representation of the Treasurer once and for all. The Treasurer's job, on behalf of the Government, is to ensure that the Australian economy is sound, strong enough and flexible enough to deal with external shocks. Those shocks can include changes in the terms of trade, rising world oil prices, disastrous droughts and overseas depressions. A whole series of things can happen to the Australian economy but the stewardship of the Government is measured by the degree to which it arms Australia against such perils. It is against this bench-mark that we will judge the performance of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at that performance. The Government came to office in 1983, giving everybody high hopes. It assembled everybody in this august chamber, the House of Representatives-representatives of people from all over Australia-and told them that they were going to do two things. It said that it would drive the Australian economy out of recession with high spending and high borrowing. That was an explicit policy. It is all there in the record of the National Economic Summit Conference. It also said that it would tie wages to inflation in line with its deal with the trade union movement. In putting up those two central elements of economic policy, the Government made two fundamental mistakes. From April 1983 the die was cast as to what would happen to Australia. Whether the Australian economy would be robust, flexible and able to deal with external shocks when they came along was, in effect, determined in April 1983.

From then on we have had a whole series of differing statements from the Government about the state of the economy. It has been very difficult to follow in recent times exactly which phase we are in. We started out with the phase of extreme optimism and extreme arrogance. The world's best Treasurer-what a joke that is now-was able to drive the Australian economy faster than any other economy and build jobs at a faster rate than anybody else, walking along the tightrope. In the process he was gambling Australia's future on the world commodity markets. The high wire act on the part of the Treasurer-he took in quite a lot of simple minded observers-went on for a considerable time.

Then things started to go wrong. Certainly, by the third quarter of last year it was very clear what was going wrong. It was clear that our inflation rate was leaping above that of our major trading partners. It was quite clear that our unemployment rate was not going to fall appreciably. It was clear that our wage costs had risen at four times the rate of those of our major trading partners. Even though real unit labour costs had fallen, our performance still compared badly with others. It became clear that our inflation rate was going to soar to four or five times that of the average rate of our trading partners. Did the Treasurer draw these disturbing facts to the attention of the Australian people? No, he did not. He kept them quiet. He kept up his arrogant and incorrect assessment of what was going on until 9 May this year, when he said to the Economic Planning Advisory Council that everything was okay. A few days later he suddenly discovered that with our bad terms of trade we were in a desperate situation and were moving towards the status of a banana republic.

A lot of water has passed under the bridge since then. Now we have had another turn of events. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer are saying that everything is all right and that everything will fall into place like the apples in a slot machine. The Treasurer, in his comments on the Australian economy, has been purely schizophrenic. One day everything is apples; the next day we are bananas. I do not know whether the Treasurer himself is apples or bananas from day to day. Certainly, the Prime Minister becomes increasingly shrill and increasingly determined to try to talk the economy up and to try to tell people that things are good. Are they good? Let us look at the report card for this Government. Let us look at each of the things that it has done and where it stands in relation to the score card after three years and seven months of stewardship. There should be no excuses. It has been in government long enough. It is all its own work.

Where do we stand? The dollar, which was worth a dollar when the Fraser Government left office, is now worth 64c. A Hawke dollar is worth 64c; a Fraser dollar was worth a dollar. Our AAA international credit rating has gone. We have been downgraded and humiliated on international financial markets. Our rating is down to AA1-a humiliation which we have never suffered previously in our history. The Treasurer, who is absent from the chamber during this debate, is responsible. Our inflation rate is 8.4 per cent and rising. The inflation rate in Japan is less than zero. Our major trading partner and competitor, Japan--

TALK.START.PARA: —Trading competitor.

—Japan, our trading competitor, has an inflation rate of less than zero. Our inflation rate of 8.4 per cent is about five times that of our trading partners. In fact, our inflation rate is now worse, in relation to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, than it has been since records were first kept by the OECD. So the score card for inflation stands at one out of 10.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned labour costs earlier. Despite the fact that real unit labour costs have gone down, over the last three years labour costs, relatively, have gone up 4 per cent compared with a rise overseas of one per cent. So we are doing worse than those with whom we compete. What about unemployment? Unemployment, which did fall to 7.6 per cent in June, is now 8.4 per cent and rising. Youth unemployment is well over 20 per cent. One of the greatest disgraces of this Government is that youth unemployment is disgracefully high. It has not gone down; it is going up again. The Priority One: Young Australia program, designed to fool the kids, has been a total failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about our relative interest rates?

—My friend the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir, asks me: What about interest rates? Before the last election in 1984, we were assured that interest rates would go down. Both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer said: `Interest rates will fall in 1985'. What did they do? They started to rise as soon as the election was over. They rose throughout 1985. In November 1985 they rose to their highest real level since the Great Depression. The prime bank rate rose to 21 per cent, and it is still 19 per cent. How many farms and businesses will be able to sustain interest rates of 19 and 20 per cent? They have been sustaining them for nearly a year. How much longer will they have to struggle? Interest rates are another failure on the part of the Government. DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the next hour or so the House will be engaged in a cognate debate on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Australian National University Amendment Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the Maritime College Amendment Bill. The principal Bill amends the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act to require higher education institutions to impose the higher education administration charge announced in the Budget, to set this charge at $250 in the 1987 academic year, to provide for annual increases in the charge to be limited to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's index of general salaries, and to establish the mechanism by which, on the Minister's estimates of institutional enrolment, Commonwealth grants are reduced by 90 per cent of the estimated revenue from the charge. The legislation also lists certain categories of students such as pension beneficiaries and recipients of student benefits who either are exempt from the charge or will receive compensatory payments to offset the up-front charge.

SPEECH.PARA: The three other Bills in respect of three specific institutions, the Australian National University, the Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Maritime College in Launceston, allow those institutions to charge the higher education fee. All of these Bills radically overturn the Government's prior approach to the financing of higher education. In fact, they turn the approach of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) on its head. I state that because these Bills introduce a tuition fee for higher education under the semantic camouflage of the term `a higher education administration charge'. Let us not mince words or, to use the favourite phrase of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), let us not insult the intelligence of the Australian people: This $250 charge is an up-front compulsory payment. It is a tuition fee in form; it is a tuition fee in application. It is a compulsory levy imposed as a condition of enrolling in a higher education course and nobody has been fooled by the phoney names and false justifications used by the Minister and the Government in their explanations and Press releases. We can call it anything we like-a higher education administration charge, an institutional donation, a student enrolment charge-but this $250 compulsory payment amounts to a tuition fee which must be paid when a student enrols for tuition. Even the Western Australian Labor Minister for Education has been honest enough to admit that in public.

The imposition of the $250 tuition fee is interesting from several important aspects. First, it exposes the full hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party's political campaign against tuition fees going back many years. Secondly, it represents the final victory of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), whose fees proposal, having been pre-emptively defeated in Caucus at the instigation of the Minister for Education, surfaced again in the context of the Budget deliberations with the backing of the Expenditure Review Committee. In this regard, this charge exposes the full degree to which Senator Ryan has lost control of the Education portfolio. Her credibility has been severely damaged. Thirdly, its introduction is a case study in political deceit and misrepresentation. Fourthly, its existence and imposition are inequitable in the discriminatory application of the same $250 rate, irrespective of the work load or course load of any student in any academic year. Finally, and most distressingly, the ad hoc panic measure implied by the introduction of this tuition fee completely fails to address any of the critical strategic issues in higher education. It carries no strategic significance or vision. It is simply an unco-ordinated revenue measure, plucked out of the air by public servants under the reluctant direction of a discredited and defeated Minister.

Only 10 days before the Budget was announced, the Minister for Education addressed a meeting at the Western Australian Institute of Technology in my home State, an institution which, prior to boundary changes, I represented. At this stage of Budget deliberations the Minister would have known of the $250 tuition fee. She would have known her Caucus victory was a pyrrhic one, that Senator Walsh had mustered the numbers in the Expenditure Review Committee to impose a tuition fee on students, and that the $250 figure had been plucked out of the air to meet the required spending cuts. She would have been fully aware of all of this, but that day, 10 days out from the so-called war-time Budget, she chose to stay in the bunker and transmit disinformation. I quote the Minister's words 10 days before the Budget was announced:
We will not impose tuition fees.

That was reported in the Australian newspaper on 9 August 1986. A member of her staff said that her comments were `unqualified in their scope'. One would have to say that the statement `we will not impose tuition fees' was as good as the Prime Minister's 1983 election statement that `we will not impose a capital gains tax'. Ten days after the statement by the Minister for Education the Budget knocked that unqualified assurance for six. This Minister for Education now has no credibility. Her promise at WAIT, 10 days before the fee was introduced, must be numbered amongst the most shamefaced examples of deceit ever practised in Australian politics.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! I point out to the honourable member for Tangney that he is going a little close to the line abusing a standing order which calls for personal reflections not to be made upon members in this House or in the other place. I ask him to take note of that.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, thank you for your guidance. I will take note of it. I ask honourable members to imagine the situation, if they were the Minister for Education, standing before a group of students, knowing that a tertiary fee was to be introduced 10 days hence in the Budget, but saying: `No, tuition fees will not be introduced'. This fee turns Labor's historical assurances on their heads. Let us recall the statements of high principle and moral sanctitude from the Labor Party in 1981, when the Liberal-National Party Government sought to raise a paltry $8m-less than a tenth of the money to be raised by this fee-by introducing fees for second and higher degrees. What did Senator Ryan say then? In the Senate on 28 October 1981 she said that the Labor Party was totally opposed to tertiary tuition fees. She claimed that tuition fees at any set amount would result in a reduction of access to education. She said that they were the thin end of the wedge. She said that fees ignored the ability to pay. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is totally opposed to the decision . . . to impose tertiary fees. . . . We will be opposing generally, and specifically, all such measures.

They are Senator Ryan's words in the Senate in October 1981. I am pleased also that shortly in this debate this matter will be debated by the honourable member for Fremantle, the Minister for Trade and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs (Mr Dawkins), who is also the Minister representing the Minister for Education in this place. I remind the House of some of his statements, which have also been exposed by this $250 fee in the Budget. As the then Labor shadow Minister for Education, the honourable member for Fremantle, paced campuses from the University of Western Australia to the James Cook University as the white knight of free education. In the early 1980s he berated the proposed $8m revenue-raising measure of the then Government, promising students that Labor would never impose tuition fees. On 21 October 1981 he told this House:
We are opposed to the re-establishment of the principle of tertiary tuition fees in general.
One day later he strengthened that declaration by saying:
The Opposition is opposed to the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees in any form.

The full significance of that phrase `in any form' cannot be overstated. Anybody who thought that Senator Walsh's premature defeat in Caucus in 1985 had destroyed his determination to reintroduce tuition fees was either a fool or mad. After all, within weeks of that Caucus decision, the Prime Minister argued that Caucus might change its mind, noting:
The Caucus has been known to change its mind on some matters. They used to have a view on uranium once.

He said that on the PM radio program on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on 16 May 1985. And well he might have used that example about uranium because we all know where Caucus stands on uranium today. The first whiff of this tuition fees reversal came in an article in the Bulletin magazine early in August, when the eminently well connected Richard Farmer wrote:

Ryan was outmanoeuvred on this occasion. . . . She was excluded from the most of the deliberations of the Expenditure Review Committee and Finance Minister Senator Peter Walsh has apparently been able to go some way towards his goal of reintroducing the fees abolished by the Whitlam Labor Government in 1973.

There can be no greater indication that the Minister for Education misled students at the Western Australian Institute of Technology in promising not to reintroduce tuition fees than the leaking of the imposition of the fee a week before the Budget by the former Labor Party campaign adviser, Richard Farmer. Either the Minister was less well informed than this journalist or she deliberately said no when she should have said yes. This compulsory fee will be paid by a greater proportion of the student population than that which paid full tuition fees prior to 1973. Even in 1972 and 1973, before those fees disappeared, nothing like 70 per cent of students paid a fee. Yet Senator Ryan's achievement, by the introduction of this fee, will be to ensure the highest proportion of fee-paying students for 40 years. The irrational manner in which this fee has been imposed deserves comment. It has been misrepresented to students and wildly misleading claims have been made in an attempt to portray the fee as a money spinner for institutions.

From the students' perspective, this $250 fee is fatally flawed. It hits full time, part time and external students at the same rate. Let us be quite clear about it. It is a $250 up-front charge whether one is doing one unit externally or a full time course load. Any higher education administrator will openly tell honourable members of his fears that this fee will reverse the historic trend towards part time and external study-a trend consistent with wider moves towards flexibility and diversity in industry and labour markets generally. We need a situation where more and more of those in the work force undertake part time or external education to upgrade their skills. We do not need to impose a government measure such as this which will strike against that sort of student enrolment. Close to half the student population in higher education study is part time or external. If one looks at the college sector, it is closer to 55 per cent. There is little logic, apart from raising money, in levying the fee at the same rate for all categories of students.

As I have said, it is likely to discourage a large proportion of part timers and an even larger number of external students. The consequences will be immense, both for the community at large, which has benefited from the involvement of students on conditions other than full time study, and for institutions such as the Deakin University or the University of New England, which rely heavily on external students for the bulk of their enrolments. A full time student in 1987 will be getting up to 10 times the education for the same $250 fee as a student enrolled in a single unit. In these circumstances, it is no wonder that some administrators are preparing themselves for massive cuts in external enrolments. Institutions, staff bodies, academic unions and student organisations have been united in criticising the absolute lack of logic inherent in this universal $250 fee.

An even more disturbing realisation is that this $250 fee will have not only an adverse effect on access for under-represented groups such as women, but also a regressive influence on the advancement of relevant skill levels and educational levels through the involvement of part time and external students which, as I say for the third time in this debate, are going to be so vital for Australia's future economy. This Government has tried to cast this $250 fee as a payment for enrolment costs. For example, the Minister for Trade, as Acting Minister for Education, in a news release dated 26 August 1986 justified the $250 universal charge, irrespective of actual work load, on the following grounds:
Part-time and external higher education students are required to pay the new administration charge at the same level as full-time students because their enrolments also generate administration costs.

That is the case, but anybody involved in higher education administration knows and will tell one, and this Government if only it will listen, that enrolling a full time student in, for example, 10 units involves much more work than enrolling an external student in, say, one unit. The fact is that students are not only enrolled in an institution; they are enrolled in a faculty, a course and individual subjects, and tutorials where applicable. Therefore a full time student enrolling in 10 units generates at least 10 times the administrative costs of an external student enrolling in one unit. Secondly, if the Government were honest in recovering enrolment costs, as the Minister for Trade has stated, the fee would be linked to the genuine costs of enrolment-for example, the clerical and data processing staff involved in this procedure-and yet it is not. The fee is not linked to any genuine costs of enrolment; the fee is indexed to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's index of general salaries, the GSI. I have with me a list of the staff classifications included in the GSI.

I ask honourable members present and those interested in this debate to consider the logic of this from the point of view of an external student who is living in Perth, for example, and who enrols in an eastern States campus. This happens and it happens often. The Government would have us believe that the student's fee is linked to enrolment-type staff wage movements. According to the document before me it is linked to an incredibly wide range of staff. An external student will have the $250 fee linked to the wage movements of such non-enrolment related staff as laboratory assistants, metal trades foremen, cleaners, gardeners and fitters and turners. An external student in Perth will be paying for the wage rises of a gardener on an eastern States campus. It is pretty hard to justify that as an enrolment related cost. But that is what this Government has tried to state. It is what the Government would have us believe.

Let us now turn to the so-called exemptions from the charge, so-called because the administrative mechanisms are either underdeveloped or transparently nonsensical. The Government has not spelt out explicitly how the exemptions will work and it is possible that some institutions, due to the vague and unexplained exemption provisions, will actually suffer a reduction in overall funding during 1987. Secondly, the compensatory payments for some categories of students, such as Austudy and Abstudy recipients, are unspecified. These students face the $250 fee up front before they enrol in February next year. Many will not be able to afford the $250 fee at that stage. Many will apply for emergency loans, further stretching the inadequate resources of campus-based financial aid organisations. Yet it is not known now whether the students will be compensated in a lump sum payment or simply by an adjustment of about $10 a fortnight in their particular allowance.

Two further points underline the stupidity of the administration of this $250 tuition fee. It is readily acknowledged that a large proportion of external students come from rural communities and that the $250 fee will adversely affect external enrolments. This will render either ineffective or wasteful the Government's $200,000 campaign to increase rural participation in higher education. This underlines again the lack of any coherent strategy and logic in the imposition of this $250 tuition fee. Secondly, over the last decade, the general salaries index has been the most rapidly increasing index of salaries compiled by CTEC. The GSI has risen much faster than genuine academic salaries indices, teaching or otherwise. The linking of the $250 fee to the GSI ensures that this fee will be at least $500 a year by the 1989 academic year. This accurate prediction assumes that the Government, having established the mechanism for recouping in part tuition fees, does not seek to inflate increases in fees to help cut outlays in future years. Is anybody seriously going to believe that the Minister for Finance will be satisfied with an indexed $250 student fee? More likely the Minister will push for fee increases, as indeed he successfully pushed for the introduction of this fee. We can expect fees to rise at Budget time much faster than the GSI index.

The claims of the Minister for Education that this $250 fee is a money spinner for institutions is also flawed fundamentally. Firstly, any variation between the Minister's estimates of eligible students and actual students enrolling each year will be redressed only in the following academic year, leaving the institutions to carry the can for 12 months. This will particularly disadvantage those institutions with a high concentration of exempt students such as pensioners or overseas students. Secondly, the Minister has tried to portray the $250 a head bonus-the 10 per cent of the fee which is to be retained by the institution-as a real gain. This ignores the adverse financial implications of the changed schedule of advance payments to institutions which took effect from 1 July this year.

Prior to 1 July 1986, institutions received their recurrent fund payments two months in advance, which allowed them to meet some of their costs and to reap interest at substantial short term rates on the money market. The change to the one-month advance payments system has terminated a source of relied upon finance to help those institutions to defray burgeoning costs. The interaction between this one month advance and the $250 fee exposes the nonsense of the Minister's claim of real gains for the institutions.

The University of New South Wales has estimated that its loss as a result of the change from a two-month to the one-month advance funding is of the order of $700,000. The $25 a head bonus from the higher education fee, on 18,000 students, will net only $450,000, even if all students at the University of New South Wales are eligible, and they will not be. This leaves the institution-I cite just one example-something like $250,000, a quarter of a million dollars, worse off in absolute resources than in June 1986.

This is the reality of higher education funding under this Government-a slick sleight-of-hand financial arrangement, superficially attractive but flawed on analysis. This measure will totally fail to compensate for the adverse effects of the shift from two-month to one-month advance payments. It will most likely cause a reduction in overall funds to higher education in 1987.

Bound as we are to allow this Government to have its Budget passed unamended, we will not oppose this legislation. This Government is entitled to have it pass through the Parliament complete, no matter how unsavoury or illogical particular measures may be. It will stand the opprobrium or otherwise from the wider community in due course. But let me make it clear. The Opposition would not have imposed this flawed, discriminatory $250 fee. The Opposition would not have imposed a measure so destructive of the trend to more flexible study patterns, so short-sighted, hypocritical and lacking in logic. This measure will do nothing to solve the crisis of capacity and technology in higher education. That crisis is manifest in the 9,000 to 14,000 qualified students who are being locked out of our higher education system, in the increasing obsolescence of the majority of equipment in higher education and in the common cutbacks in essential education services such as library hours and tuition, as institutions are forced by the current financial squeeze to place restrictions on their activities.

This Government is presiding over the demise of our higher education system. It is in total disarray, unable to meet either the demand for student places or the needs of industry for well-qualified graduates in state of the art technology. Labor's answer is to provide for only marginal increases in enrolment without funding additional student places at marginal cost. This only increases the burdens on other sections of higher education institutions-a zero sum game, the ultimate consequence of which is a reduced capacity to return a net educational benefit to the community at large. As I have said, we will not be opposing this measure. However, we will campaign against it vigorously. When it has passed through both the House of Representatives and the Senate, the community, in not too short a time, will have its opportunity to pass a judgment not only on the introduction of this illogical measure but also on the fact that this Government is failing the nation's needs by not providing for a strong, vigorous and expanding higher education sector.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the list of those who will speak in this debate, it is noticeable that our side of the House has four members from Tasmania listed-myself representing Bass, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). The reason for that is the point made by the shadow Minister for Education, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), about the effects this charge will have on part time and external students. In no State will that effect be felt more than in Tasmania, a State that is more decentralised than any other in its educational services and has more external and part time students than any other State in Australia. That is why so many Tasmanians want the opportunity to voice their criticisms of this group of measures. It is interesting that only three members from the Government side are speaking. That is a measure of the concern that is felt by back bench members of the Australian Labor Party and the difficulties they have faced in the Caucus in trying to put these measures to the public. They know that the young people in this community are particularly concerned about the imposition of these measures.

One of the institutions in Tasmania about which I want to talk is the Australian Maritime College. The Australian Maritime College is a unique institution; it is the only one of its type in Australia. It currently has somewhere in the vicinity of 321 full time students but it also conducts many short courses and other courses for people from the Royal Australian Navy, from the Pacific islands and from different areas right around Australia. It is interesting to look at the second reading speech of the Minister for Trade, who represents the Minister for Education in this place, about the effects of the $250 fee. Figures are quoted at the end of the speech. The revenue collected by the college in 1987 is estimated to be $69,000, which will result in the recurrent grant for 1987 being reduced by $62,000.

I think it is somewhat of a con to believe, as this Government is trying to tell us, that this fee will help defray the administration costs of institutions. It really is a con because what is happening is that one is taking with one hand and having it taken away from recurrent grants with the other. Maybe the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who is at the table, or whoever responds to this debate will explain how those figures got into the second reading speech. As I understand it, the triennium submission to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission quoted completely different figures. In fact, $94,750 will be collected, of which $85,275 will go to the Commonwealth. If one takes the 1986 figures, the amount collected was estimated at $80,250, of which $72,225 would go to the Government. Something is obviously wrong there. If those sorts of errors appear in what is one of the smallest budgets of an institution affected by this fee, one wonders what the effects might be on the estimation of the fees to be collected and the effects on recurrent grants of institutions right around the country.

One of the issues that will be affected at the Maritime College is one I raised with the Minister as long ago as August 1985 and it runs in parallel with the new fee that has been introduced. I refer to the effect on the variation of tertiary education assistance scheme benefits from the May economic statement. It affects particularly single independent status students. As I have said, at the Maritime College most students come from interstate and some are foreign students. Let me give an interesting example of how this fee, in addition to the changes to TEAS, will affect students at this college and also the ability of the college to bring extra students to it. We heard a speech from the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) on how we must lift the educational standards of engineers and all the ratings, whatever they be, within the maritime industry, and here we have a national institution trying to do this. I take the example of a student who will be affected by enrolling in the first year of the bachelor of applied science fisheries technology course. He is single, 28 years age, and his home is located on Thursday Island, which is about as far away from Tasmania as one could get. He recently visited the office of the Registrar to say that, because of the high travel costs that would be incurred, he had doubts that he would be able to continue with his course unless a decision to amend the TEAS application is made. In addition, he will have another $250 to pay. So we might be losing a student from Thursday Island. It is those types of examples about which this Government has not thought in imposing these fees.

I asked the Minister in August, and we have continued to ask the Minister, whether the Government would consider reviewing the single independent status as it applies to the Maritime College. It applies to about 50 students who come from far-flung areas of Australia. If we are to maintain and enhance the excellence of the academic achievements of those we wish to go into our maritime industry we ought to be looking a little more carefully at unique institutions such as this Maritime College and how such fees might impose upon them.

Early this week or late last week the Minister for Transport brought down a report of the Maritime Industry Development Committee which recommended that all new entrants into the shipping industry undergo a common training course at the Australian Maritime College for a period of 19 weeks and that the college also offer an intensive 10-week retraining course for those already involved in the industry. I welcome that committee finding. I give credit to the Minister for the positive step he has taken. If it is instituted we will see an increase in the academic levels and training for our maritime industry people. I wonder how this fee will affect those who enrol in those courses, which will now be compulsory for entry into the maritime industry. Perhaps the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) ought to look at the matter together. On the very second page of the 1985 annual report of the Maritime College-I have it here-the Minister for Transport is pictured driving his new simulator at the college. He is quite happy to get the credit for being there when things are good. But the bottom line for any of these institutions is a continuous good solid flow of students. The imposition of the fee in the tertiary education assistance scheme area will mean that students will suffer and that courses will be made unattractive. This will do nothing to ensure the continuity of the success of the Maritime College.

I would like also to turn to the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology which is based in Launceston. This institution has about 2,220 full time students. By 1991, on current projections, it is hoping to get the figure up to nearly 2,750. The interesting thing about that institution is that 54 per cent of its students are part time or external students. That is a particularly high percentage. It is estimated now by the college that the imposition of this $250 fee across the board, without any pro rata application at all, will see an immediate 20 per cent drop-off of part timers next year. That is a dramatic fall.

One wonders what the reasons are behind the introduction of this fee. We heard earlier from the honourable member for Tangney that there is a shortfall of 9,000 to 14,000 full time places available in tertiary institutions around this nation. I recall some several months ago the vice-chancellors of this nation expressing extreme concern about this state of affairs. If one looks closely-I do not have time to canvass all the issues now-at the mechanisms behind the funding for equivalent full time students, EFTS, one can draw this conclusion if one wants to ascribe to conspiracy theories: Is not the aim of this $250 fee perhaps to force out part time and external students and therefore leave space, as it were, for full time students in existing institutions and thereby avoid the necessity of creating or establishing further tertiary institutions to take up the 9,000 to 14,000 young Australians who want to get a full time education? I leave that question to be answered by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), who is at the table, or the Minister who will respond to this debate. However, I think that this is a legitimate argument to be putting; it is one that requires an answer. I think it is incumbent on the Government to respond to questioning of the way that this fee has been put down without any regard being paid to the gap in terms of the 9,000 to 14,000 student places that are needed.

There was a hue and cry in Tasmania when this fee was introduced and, of course, that reaction was heard by the Minister for Education. Tasmanian members of this place, such as I, responded to this fee, as did the Minister for Education in Tasmania, the Hon. Peter Rae, a man who is well known in this place because he served for many years in the other place as a senator. Peter Rae drew attention immediately to the absurdity of introducing a fee which has no pro rata application. It is a fee which is going to penalise part time and external students. As I have said, it will result in perhaps a 20 per cent reduction in the number of part time students attending the tertiary institution in Launceston.

Peter Rae is not a person who comes to education without any experience. He took part in the education debates in the other chamber on many occasions and he also served for many years on the Australian National University Council. Perhaps the Federal Minister for Education ought to talk to a person such as Peter Rae who now has to administer State education areas, who knows the importance of trying to find money to fund educational facilities and who is used to trying to get funds out of the Commonwealth to fund institutional activities in a State where decentralisation is a fact of life. It is no wonder that he said:
This fee directly attacks the attempts to decentralise Tasmanian tertiary education.

As indeed it does. The reintroduction of across the board fees of $250 is a direct blow to any chances of significantly improving Australia's appalling low tertiary education retention rates. As I have said, there is no provision for the payment on a pro rata basis of the fee for part time students and this will hit Tasmanian tertiary education institutions, particularly the Tasmanian Institute of Technology, which have such a high proportion of part time students. I wonder why it is that the Minister did not consider this issue when the whole question of fees was being discussed.

When one goes back to the announcement of the decision to impose a fee, it is interesting to see some of the responses that were made in the Tasmanian media. Perhaps the most succinct approach to this issue was contained in the editorial of the Launceston Examiner, which is acknowledged-I am not quoting from it just because it is a paper in my electorate-as a good balanced newspaper which looks at issues objectively. The editorial stated:
. . . but its application to part-time and external studies students is ludicrous.

One can but agree with that. The editorial pointed out another issue, and that was that the Centre for Continuing Education for Teachers in Tasmania, which has about 900 enrolments, will be particularly hard hit as most students take only one or two subjects a year. If there is anything we need in this country at a time when technology is changing so quickly, at a time when we are trying to enhance computer studies and so on-one only has to read the book of the Minister of Science (Mr Barry Jones) to appreciate the changes that are taking place-it is continuing education and those who must get continuing education more than any other are teachers. So one must wonder at the fact that the Centre for Continuing Education for Teachers is to be hit so adversely by this fee. It is something that requires a response from the Minister.

The Federal Government argues that the $250 fee is an administrative fee and not a tuition fee. Quite frankly, that is just semantic nonsense. It does not mean anything. We know what it is-it is a fee which is going to affect very dramatically part time and external studies student enrolments. This fee will be imposed on the students at the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology at Launceston, 54 per cent of whom are part timers. There will be an automatic drop-off of 20 per cent in enrolments. This will happen in a State which has decentralised education arrangements under which many students undertake external studies. The fee is being imposed at a time when we need to be lifting the retention rates, as was so eloquently pointed out by the honourable member for Tangney. It is being imposed at a time when we need education and training if Australia is to improve its competitive position in this world. To see that happen and for the Government to rely on the sort of semantic nonsense that we have heard is really just beyond the pale. If anything, this unjust tax on part time and external students should be abolished straight away and at least consideration should be given to the introduction of a fee on a pro rata basis.

Finally, it was interesting to hear the honourable member for Canning refer to his meeting with the vice-chancellors. I wonder what the vice-chancellors really did say to him and whether he gave a full report to this House of what they said to him. I have a letter from Professor Kevin Marjoribanks, the Acting Vice-Chancellor of the University of Adelaide. It is interesting to note that not one Labor member from South Australia has been prepared to put his head up and speak on this very vital issue. The letter talks about the effects that the fee will have on the University of Adelaide. If talks about the possible budgetary effects of a loss of approximately $2m in income if the university declined to impose and collect the charge. That goes back to the point that I made about the direct effect on recurrent grants to institutions of the imposition of this fee. Interestingly, the Vice-Chancellor said:

It was also suggested . . . that I should ensure that you are aware of the concerns expressed in the letter from the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee to the Minister for Education, Senator The Honourable Susan Ryan. I have, therefore, included the text of that letter which stated:
The letter goes on-obviously I cannot quote it all-for two more pages. However, I would like to quote one or two points that were made. The vice-chancellors of all the universities in Australia said:

. . . that the nature of the charge will impact adversely on the Government's program of participation and equity in education. The Government has actively encouraged, through its policies, the enrolment of geographically isolated and economically disadvantaged students, and women in higher education. These policies have been successful and many such people have enrolled particularly as part-time students. The Vice-Chancellors feel that it is inequitable that part-time students, including many that are enrolled externally, will be required to pay the same level of charges as full-time students.

There we have it-some of the most learned men in this country are telling this Government that part time students and external students are being treated inequitably. This Minister and this Party sends into this place to speak on this vital debate three people of whom the public of Australia probably has never heard. It is an absolute disgrace. Let us see what else they said:
On 26 August, Mr. John Dawkins-
that is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs in this country, who looks about 65 years of age to me-
. . . during your absence overseas, stated the administrative costs do not vary greatly between part-time and full-time students.
Then the vice-chancellors said:
A study undertaken within one university would seem to contradict this argument.

So the Government has not even done its research properly. It does not even know the difference between the effects this fee will have on a part time student, an external student or a full time student. The final point I make is that there are obviously going to be vast administrative problems with the introduction of this fee. The vice-chancellors also said:

. . . there will be problems in regard to the collection of the fee, particularly if there is a concerted campaign amongst students to boycott its payment. Universities will not be able to enrol students unless they pay the fee and if the boycott campaign is successful, enrolments in 1987 will be thrown into confusion.

If the students of Australia campaign against paying this fee, I do not know what will happen, but if they do, come the commencement of the term in 1987, this Government, through the imposition of this fee, without thinking of the effects that it will have, might be faced with a rebellion by students. I do not know whether it is treasonable for a member of parliament to stand up in this place and urge students to rebel and not pay the fee, but I certainly know that it is incumbent upon a member of parliament to point out to this country that if fees such as these are introduced and if students, especially the part time and external students, are going to be hit with them, in my view when they go to enrol they would be justified in refusing to pay.

If I have read the vice-chancellors' letter correctly, they are saying: `Really, we would quite welcome it because it might make the Government see sense'. I do not think the debate today will be the end of this matter. It might well be just the beginning. The beginning of 1987 might see the students of this country expressing their view in a way which will really sink home to the Government. There is one thing that this Government is sure of, that is, that it wants to be re-elected. It is going to do everything it can, as it did with the Priority One campaign, and spend as much money as it can trying to con the youth of Australia. But one cannot con sensible people, and it is about time this Government realised it.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that those here representing the Opposition in this debate on education are the very few people from the Opposition who can honestly oppose administrative charges by this Government on students. We have in this debate four Tasmanian members of parliament and the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), all rainforest wets.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I find that term offensive. I thought it was a standing order of this place that honourable members are referred to by their seats.
—If the honourable member for Eden- Monaro made an offensive comment towards anyone in this House I request him to withdraw that.
—I am very happy to withdraw if the honourable members find it offensive.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw.

—I withdraw unequivocally, Madam Deputy Speaker. But I do make the point that there are dries and wets in the Opposition. Today in this debate we are hearing from the wets, other than of course, the Opposition spokesperson on education, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), who has kept quiet about his real beliefs about the real choice of educational options because he knows full well that he is not going to talk about those proposals until and unless-and I emphasise `unless', because I do not think it is going to happen-the Opposition comes into power and puts his educational options into effect. His proposals would soak up expertise and funds for education by private institutions. He would have students who do not now pay for their education paying for it through loans, and not just $250 a year. He would have them paying for the cost of their education after their graduation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the wets, whether they are Tasmanian or Queensland wets or bad weather socialists, will quite happily attack fees. How are those opposite going to cope with the majority of their associates and how are they going to resolve their problems with their own Party as it works out its deregulation and its dry policies on education, whereby people will have to pay for their education, either now or in the hereafter?

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) is associated with Budget decisions to increase funds for tertiary institutions by 2.6 per cent in real terms in 1987. There will be an administrative charge of $250 to help the budgets of institutions. This will apply to all students. But there are exemptions. Pensioners and beneficiaries eligible for allowances as full time students are among those exempted. Others will have their benefits increased by the value of the charge. In addition, needy students will be able to apply to institutions for assistance from the $11m scheme of low-cost loans and grants which was established last year.

The increased charges also involve amendments to Acts relating to the Canberra College of Advanced Education, the Australian National University and the Australian Maritime College in Launceston, all of which serve the region of Eden-Monaro particularly well. The Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Australian National University, as well as being national educational institutions, provide in full for people in the region who want the type of training they offer, along with technical and further education institutions in Canberra, Queanbeyan, Goulburn, Cooma, Bega, Moruya and Milton. The Maritime College at Launceston also provides a very important service to this region, particularly to the fishing industry.

Initiatives taken by these three institutions alone justify the 2.6 per cent real increase overall. An example of the way in which one institution has introduced efficient rationalisation is that the ANU improved automation in its library last year. For the first time it has brought its classification material together in one main building. The data base has been increased by approximately 610,000 records. The University is challenged by higher campus numbers and lower staff numbers. Although the ANU is faced with reducing some of its commitments to adult education, the Centre for Continuing Education-I compliment the Council of which I know the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) are members; they responded to requests that I made to continue funding-has played a very important role in the south-east region of New South Wales, particularly in Eden-Monaro, where it has played a full role in three search conferences, two of which were conducted on feral animal control and one concerned the future of Montague Island. The centre has resolved local conflicts and brought expertise in the management of conferences into effect. It has linked a very important educational institution with what is going on in the community. So, I compliment those honourable members on the way they represented community forces in ensuring the continuation of that program.

The Maritime College in Launceston shows us how the good use of funding can provide equipment which benefits a range of seafaring and related industries. The college has developed a gas generator trainer, a simulator which models the operation of inert gas systems installed on modern tankers and which was ready for use in 1986. The equipment will be used extensively for teaching both on short courses for experienced seafarers and on full time engineering and nautical studies courses. As well, the college has given assistance to other countries. Mr J. Seaton, a senior lecturer at the Maritime College, made a five-week visit to Fiji to assist in the development of courses on refrigeration which were conducted by a local educational authority there.

In the School of Fisheries in 1985 for the first time a Bachelor of Applied Science (Fisheries Technology) course was run, with 18 initial enrolments. These students were joined mid-year by eight students who received advanced standing after completing the first year of the Fisheries Technology Diploma course which the new degree course replaces. The college vessel, Bluefin, continued her program of training cruises for School of Fisheries students. In addition, in July she visited Jervis Bay-again in the New South Wales and Australian Capital Territory region-to take part in underwater filming of trawl gear-a program conducted by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the South Australian Department of Fisheries and Wildlife and funded by the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account, a Commonwealth-funded account known as FIRTA.

The equipment acquired by the Maritime College School of Fisheries during 1985, mainly for the new seafood handling laboratory, and designed to Department of Primary Industry standards, will give students practical experience of the operations of a fish-handling establishment. It does what is very necessary today; it not only looks at primary industry but also tries to link it with manufacturing. A fish-filleting seminar was presented by the new School of Fisheries lecturers. The seminar was aimed at fisheries students, restaurateurs and marketing and training personnel in the fishing industry.

The maritime library, run by the Maritime College, has played a great role in providing access not only to undergraduates but also to many other people in research and other areas. Among the specialist programs there is a resources centre in the college which has installed a ship-handling simulator which has proved its worth both in teaching and as a research and development tool. During the latter half of the year, presentations on the value of the simulator to port authorities were given to people from Western Australia and Queensland. Several improvements have been carried out to existing facilities at the centre. Space for the radar and navigation simulator was extended to allow for larger training groups. The software for the diesel engine simulator was extensively modified for better system performance and easier maintenance.

The Canberra College of Advanced Education has also played an important role in the region. In April 1985 a highly successful research-based Master of Arts in Administration course was accredited. The panel for reaccreditation of the course work masters degree in public administration met in that year. In the School of Applied Science, the CCAE reached agreement that the college should commence a three-year program in general nursing, with an initial intake of 90 nurses in 1986. A program has been developed and submitted for accreditation and recruitment of staff and students has commenced. Again, that is a great boost not only for people in Canberra but also for people in areas such as Goulburn, Queanbeyan, Cooma and the south coast of New South Wales.

The CCAE has a good record in educational studies. Of the full time students who graduated from the college in 1984, 67 per cent gained full time employment in 1985; 17 per cent were in part time employment and seeking full time positions; and a further 8 per cent were in part time employment and not seeking full time positions; one per cent were unavailable for employment; 5 per cent had returned to study; and 2 per cent were unemployed. That is not a bad record for an important educational institution in this region.

In the School of Environmental Design, the CCAE has shown how it can relate to local community needs. In the architecture course the practice of running projects concerned with community needs is important. Projects include a residential complex for the elderly, a parish centre in Erindale and an environmental centre in Acton. Students from the architecture and landscape architecture courses worked together to complete an inter-disciplinary project for the West Circular Quay area of Sydney. The courses in building and quantity surveying had their first graduates in 1985. All graduates are in worth while employment, and it has been very good to see them promoted to senior positions.

During the year a number of changes to the courses of study in the School of Information Sciences took place. The computer science undergraduate course has been proposed for accreditation, leading to the award of Bachelor of Applied Science in Computer Science. This course will serve to complement the undergraduate course in computing studies, which has been submitted for reaccreditation with the same basic structure but with a strengthening of the information systems emphasis. I repeat that in information science, particularly in computing studies, students from the Canberra College of Advanced Education have had some very great achievements in employment. That course has a very good reputation in industry. In the School of Liberal Studies, the Centre for Secretarial Communication and Systems held three residential courses on the development of managerial skills for the Department of Foreign Affairs, each having an enrolment of 14 students. The Centre for Sports Studies admitted the first students in the master's degree level course in sports studies. This course has three different strands: Sports science, sports administration and sports humanities. It also includes a substantial research thesis component.

These three institutions, along with many others throughout Australia, have shown that the 2.6 per cent increase in funding by the Federal Government, tied up with the $250 administrative charge to students, with some very considerate and well thought out ways in which students in need can avoid those charges, will make a further contribution to education in Australia.
