—We do have dynamic growth in Queensland, but unfortunately it is not infectious for national economic activity. It is against that backdrop that I approach the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Australian National University Amendment Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the Maritime College Amendment Bill and the introduction of tertiary fees, as previewed in the Budget Speech. No changing of the words can get away from the fact that the Hawke-Keating Labor Government has imposed a fee on tertiary education students. I was disappointed to hear this announcement because for so long, as far as the Press was concerned, and this was what appeared to be the truth, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) indicated that she was fighting tooth and nail to ward off the pressures to have the fee reimposed. However, the Expenditure Review Committee was too strong for her. In the Government's wisdom-thankfully for our side of the House, that will ensure that we are the government after the next election-it decided to tax the future leaders and business people of our country.

SPEECH.PARA: Regardless of the title, a dollar is a dollar, no matter how it is spent or what the Minister places on it. A fee is a fee, whether it is called an administrative fee or a tertiary fee. People have to pay the fee no matter what it is called, and it comes out of the same pockets. We in the National and Liberal parties submit that it is a nonsense to impose this cost burden at all. The administrative problems of collecting this fee will fall on institutions, placing a greater strain on the bursars' offices. Likewise, the burden of pursuing a non-payer of a loan which is extended by the institution to cover this fee will also be the responsibility of the college or university. It goes without saying that the nightmare of trying to collect this money will end up costing more than the original sum and hence not be worth the effort. In the end, if a student drops out after a short time attending classes, his fee will not be refunded on a pro rata basis. This charge will fall on all students, whether they are part time, full time, or external studies students.

One would surely assume that in a society based on justice part time and external studies students would not generate the same amount of paperwork as full time students, yet the cost to the students will be the same. Was this done to encourage more full time students or was it to discourage the part time and external studies students? Part time students fall into several categories, but basically they consist of two types: Those who are working and want to further extend their knowledge of their profession, and those who are in the process of retraining for another occupation. There are housewives preparing themselves for re-entry into the work force. There are people who cannot financially afford to attend a tertiary institution on a full time basis. In the end, the cost to these people will be greater because, being part time, it will take longer to complete the degree program. Only today, like you I presume, Mr Deputy Speaker, I received in the mail a letter from the Vice-Chancellor's Office of the University of Adelaide. The letter states:

The Vice-Chancellors feel that it is inequitable that part-time students, including many that are enrolled externally, will be required to pay the same level of charge as full-time students. This will mean that part-time students will be paying $2,000 and more for a course for which a full-time student might only be paying a little over $750.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two thousand dollars?

—Yes, $2,000 for a part time student. This is the fellow who is out there in the work place. The honourable member for Fairfax made a very pertinent interjection. Such people want to upgrade their skills in their own time, not in the employer's time, doing a part time course. Yet they are discriminated against by having to pay $2,000 to complete the course, whereas a full time student has to pay $750.
—A significant number are country students, too.

—As the honourable member for Mallee says, a significant number of these people are country students. Quite often they have to drive 100 miles or 150 kilometres a couple of times a week at their own expense and in addition they are going to be saddled with this fee. I do not understand why part time and external students should be discriminated against by this flat rate charge.
—That is a big penalty.
—It is just too much, because these people are not big income earners.
—Would the honourable member please address the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I accept your advice and certainly I will follow that advice. I was just making the point that part time and external students are discriminated against by the flat rate charged. At this late stage I appeal to the Government to go away and sit down and quietly analyse its decision to introduce this fee. Maybe then it will see fit to follow the advice and suggestions of the Vice-Chancellor of the Adelaide University.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I think it needs to be emphasised that students who are presently studying at universities enrolled on the basis that they would not have to pay an administration fee for the remaining years of their courses. Those who sit opposite might say that $500 over two years is not much for the second and third years of a course, but I just want to let them know that in many cases $500 is too much for students to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might have to drop out.

—It could be, as the honour- able member for Gippsland so rightly and appropriately said, that they will be forced to drop out of their courses. I cannot understand this. Maybe we in the National Party, because of our extremely honest approach to politics, cannot really understand this. The two honourable members and the Minister in the other place who represent Canberra in the Parliament have stood up in the Parliament and said: `We are a party of principle'. I get a bit sick when I listen to that sort of stuff. They have said: `We believe that interest rates on housing in the Australian Capital Territory should remain at an all time low because an agreement was made and that agreement should stand the test of time'. They say this and they get great kudos in the electorate for doing so. If that is the principle, why do not Government members establish the same principle for people who have gone to universities on the understanding that no administrative fee would be charged? For students who have been there for one year the Government is proposing to impose the fee in the second and third years. If the Government is going to have cheap housing loans for those who live in the Australian Capital Territory because a contract was made, it seems to me to be quite logical, and certainly honest, to request the Government to make the same sort of rule for those who attend tertiary education institutions as far as the administration fee is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: In these days of job scarcity and students leaving school earlier, the under educated will not be as willing to place any strain on their employment situation in order to take up a study program if they have to pay an administration fee. They will cling to their hard-fought for jobs which, in the end, will leave them with limited skills and knowledge of the world around them. In case honourable members opposite question that, I indicate that in 1983 Australia sent our best young tradesmen to the International Skills Olympics in Austria. Sure, it was the first time we had competed, but it is distressing to note that we did very badly indeed. Korea topped the competition, winning 20 medals; Austria scored 19 medals; Taiwan won 15 medals; Japan won 13 medals; Germany won 12 medals; and Switzerland won 11 medals. Australia did not even win one medal. Australia was once a great country. In the words of Dorothea Mackellar, we love our sunburnt country. We won no medals at Austria. We need to upgrade our skills. Being beaten by Japan and Germany did not come as a surprise, but being beaten by Korea and Taiwan, countries normally seen by Australia as inferior, should be food for national thought.

One of the reasons why we do not have the skills in a wide ranging area is the inflexibility imposed on companies by the multiplicity of trade classifications. I would hope that we can get away from some of those outdated work practices so that people will have more skills and opportunities to have meaningful work. We want people to upgrade their skills, to go to colleges of advanced education and to participate in TAFE courses. At present we are not internationally competitive and we need all the brains and imagination that this country can produce in order to bring around our economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The future of Australia depends on it.

—As the honourable member for Cowper says, the future of Australia depends on our having an educated work force so that people can go out and compete. The honourable member for Cowper has fired my imagination a little because the point that he made deserves to be brought to the forefront of the attention of the Australian people. I say this: It is absolute nonsense to say: `Buy Australian'. On behalf of the people I represent, I say that the only allegiance I have got to buy Australian made is if the Australian made product is the best and the cheapest. That is my allegiance. All this other stuff is a heap of humbug, hypocrisy and absolute rot.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to get back to the subject of the debate.

—I am pointing out that we can produce the best for the cheapest only if we have educated people. The honourable member for Cowper directed me along that line because he supports the view that we need top quality people, well-educated people and people who can go out and have the skills that will allow us to become internationally competitive.
—People such as the honourable member for Cowper.

—The honourable member for Cowper has made a distinguished contribution in this Parliament. This will not only bring in additional overseas revenue but also create additional demand for Australian products and assist our economy. I feel very deeply that the reintroduction of tertiary fees is a retrograde step for those interested in expanding their knowledge of the world and developing appropriate work skills. This country needs an educated work force capable of pre-empting the changes occurring in our economy and able to help all of us pull through the structural readjustments confronting our nation. Yet this Government has sought to penalise those who want to further their education skills-people on whom we will be most dependent in the future. This is a very sad and totally unnecessary move on the Government's behalf. It is just another broken promise and an alteration to Labor's policy and platform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an extraordinary speech that we just listened to. I have never heard such hypocrisy in this place.
—I rise on a point of order. The honourable member for Fraser used unparliamentary language by implying that the contribution of a fellow parliamentarian could be described as `hypocrisy'.
—The honourable member for Groom has been in the House long enough to know that that is not a point of order.
—Several of the senior colleagues of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), have advocated tertiary fees.

—I rise on a point of order. In respect of your earlier ruling, it has been the ruling of many Speakers since I have been in this House that the word `hypocrisy' is unparliamentary language. On that basis, I ask the honour- able member for Fraser to withdraw that reference.

—The honourable member knows that there was a list of unparliamentary terms that is no longer in use. That word has been used quite frequently in recent years and I cannot uphold the objection to the use of that word.

—The term is accurately used in this case because several of the senior colleagues of the honourable member have publicly advocated the introduction of tertiary fees, and he knows it. The honourable member is simply indulging in posturing which he knows would be revealed were his Party ever to be in government.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I say this in all seriousness and I excuse you if you did not hear the remark because I saw you having consultations with the Clerk: The honourable member for Fraser implied that I was posturing, that what I said I knew was not true. I believe that ill becomes him and it reflects very deeply on his character. If he treats honesty and integrity with that sort of off the cuff remark, in effect he is belittling himself and I am concerned that in doing that he belittles the Parliament.
—As those words are offensive to the honourable member for Groom I ask the honourable member for Fraser to withdraw them.
—I withdraw with reluctance, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The honourable member knows that he must withdraw.

—I withdraw. I repeat that the facts of this situation are that some of the senior colleagues of the honourable member for Groom have publicly advocated the introduction of tertiary fees and that the honourable member appeared to be speaking against the principles of his Party and those of his coalition colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Australian National University Amendment Bill amend the Australian National University Act 1946 and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act 1967. They provide for the collection of a higher education administration charge of $250 by the university and the Canberra College of Advanced Education. This was announced in the 1986 Budget, as was the exemption of many categories of students from payment of such a charge because of their low incomes. These Bills have been introduced because the ANU and the CCAE are institutions which come under the Commonwealth Government whilst other universities and colleges in Australia come under the control of the State governments. These arrangements will lead to the collection of an estimated $1.6m by the university and $1.5m by the college, enabling a reduction in the recurrent grants of $1.4m to both of these institutions. There will be no extra cost in collecting the charge as the honourable member for Groom suggested, because universities and colleges already collect student and sports union membership charges and this charge can be collected at the same time.

I deeply regret the decision to impose the charge and recognise that it will deter some who would otherwise do so from beginning a degree or diploma course. However, it must also be recognised that those who gain a degree or diploma have far better than average chances of finding employment and are likely to earn higher salaries than otherwise would have been possible. I would have wished that the imposition of such a charge had not been necessary but it is easy to understand why it has been done. This Budget has been, of necessity, a Budget of restraint and it is essential that the restraint be shared fairly and equitably. This Budget does this.

The majority of university entrants will not be greatly disadvantaged by the charge and most of those who would suffer hardship will be exempted. Indeed, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is to be wholeheartedly congratulated for her firm and principled opposition to the reintroduction of full cost recovery fees, which is what the Opposition would like. Such fees undoubtedly would have caused widespread hardship and abandonment of higher education, and would have necessitated the introduction of an unwieldy system of scholarships. These considerations, however, would not deter the Opposition from introducing tertiary fees. As I have already said, several senior coalition front benchers have advocated the introduction of tertiary fees so we know that they would introduce them if Australia should ever be unlucky enough to be governed by a Liberal-National Party coalition again.

The introduction of fees at tertiary institutions must be opposed. They would increase inequality and discourage participation in higher education, particularly by mature-age students, women, migrants of non-English speaking backgrounds, those with no history of tertiary education in their families and those living a long distance from colleges and universities. The fact that the removal of university fees by the Whitlam Government did not lead to an immediate increase in participation in higher education by all these groups is no argument for the return of tertiary education fees.

Other measures in addition to the abolition of fees are necessary to effect a change in the social composition of tertiary students, to make them more representative of Australians as a whole and thus transform Australian higher education into a more powerful instrument of individual opportunity for the disadvantaged-as well as for everyone else-and a developer of skills for the social and economic development of our country. As Dr Don Anderson of the Australian National University, who has done more research on this than anybody else in the country, has pointed out, the removal of university fees was a necessary but not a sufficient condition for creating a more egalitarian social mix in our universities and colleges. As a result of extensive analysis of data covering a period of 30 years he has come to the conclusion that `a substantial shift towards democratising higher education would require changes elsewhere in the system, not simply removal of the barriers at the point of entry'.

One of the necessary elements of this change must be the creation of more places in a wide range of tertiary institutions for more students. Australia has a lower participation rate in tertiary and further education than some other comparable countries and many sectors of our economy face shortages of skilled personnel. It is therefore important to provide tertiary places for as many capable and motivated applicants as possible in order to develop the skill base, research capacity and management ability of Australians. This is essential if we are to expand and diversify the economy of this country.

The Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education, both of which are located in my electorate, have played an outstanding role in education, training and research, not only for Canberra but for the nation as a whole. The college has trained many teachers and contributed towards the training of public servants and staff for the private sector in many fields, including computer programming, media work and office management. Recently nursing and a couple of fields of engineering have been added to the courses offered there. The ANU is a world class institution in many fields of study and research, including many of the social sciences and humanities and the physical, biological and medical sciences. Much brilliant research in the Asian and Pacific regions has been sponsored by the ANU.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down. Bob wants to speak.
—It is quite clear that the Opposition is not in the least interested in this very important subject.
—The honourable member for Groom will cease his interjections.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Increased funding for both the college and the university must have a high priority in an era when Australia is seeking to maximise self-reliant development and export growth. The introduction of the administrative charge will make little difference to the outstanding scholarship at both institutions. It will make a small contribution to increasing the number of tertiary places without significantly interfering with the capacity of people to attend. It is certainly not the thin end of the wedge of the introduction of tertiary fees. There is no way in which tertiary fees will be introduced. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986[COGNATE BILLS:AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL 1986CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986MARITIME COLLEGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Australian National University Amendment Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the Maritime College Amendment Bill. I address my remarks particularly to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. It is interesting to note that only three Government members have participated in this debate. The first, who spoke for 20 minutes, did not refer for almost 17 minutes to any of the cognate Bills under consideration. He talked about Alan Bond. He talked about several other matters such as industrial relations. He said that the Opposition had no policies. He spoke about private universities and about real estate. That illustrates the lack of concern for education of the Government members who have spoken on this set of Bills today. If this legislation is genuinely for the benefit of Australian young people, Government members could have given positive reasons why the Government has brought in this legislation. They were unable to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill brings in a $250 `administration charge', to use the words of the Government. But as has already been stated quite clearly and categorically, it does not matter what the Government wants to call that charge; it is a tertiary fee. It is compulsory on enrolment. Students enrolling next year in our tertiary institutions will be forced, before they can take up any studies whatsoever, to pay a $250 administrative fee. A range of students are exempt. They include students being paid the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance, full fee paying overseas students, post-graduate award students and Abstudy students plus full time and part time student pensioners. A total of 114,000 people are exempt. That leaves something like 160,000 students who will have to pay these fees. The charge is indexed on an annual basis according to Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission processes for adjusting administrative salary costs. As our Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), noted, these costs do not necessarily relate to the administrative costs which this charge is supposed to cover. This Bill also provides for loans and grants to needy students.
This measure indicates a U-turn by the Government in regard to tertiary fees. An article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald in November 1984 states:
The Government has no intention of re-introducing the fees because the Labor Party's policy provides for free tertiary education.

The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) made that statement. This measure is another illustration of this Government telling the people one thing, going to an election, being voted into government and then doing a U-turn when in government. It was against tertiary fees but now it has introduced them. I turn to another statement which backs up the statement I have just quoted. On 21 March 1986 the Minister for Education put out a Press release which stated:
The Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan, today closed the tertiary fees debate-
which had been raging within the Australian Labor Party-
by assuring students that the fees option will not be considered by the Hawke Government.

That statement was made as late as March 1986. The honourable member for Tangney, who led this debate for the Opposition, stated that even up to 10 days before the Budget was brought down the Minister was saying that the Government would not impose tuition fees. The Government cannot go on making U-turns and maintain credibility with the Australian people. Most Australians now find the Government to be lacking in credibility. This measure is another instance of the Government promising something that it did not deliver. Once the Minister was defeated in Cabinet-the Budget had to be brought down-she wanted to place the guilt on students. It is interesting to note one of the Minister's Press releases when she was in China:
If students don't pay-
these institutions their $250-
their own institutions will be out of pocket. And that is something students need to consider.

In other words, instead of the Minister facing up to the fact that she was not able to get her way and facing the flak fairly and squarely with the students of Australia, she wanted to change the emphasis and place the guilt on the students. She said that if students did not pay their institutions were going to lose out; that it was their fault.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blackmail.
—It is blackmail. The Minister ought to be remonstrated with by her colleagues for making that type of insinuation about Australian students. She went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: If they don't pay, higher education will be $97m worse off; that is the amount we are taking off grants.

The guilt ought to lie with the Minister and not with the students of Australia. Another point I want to raise in this debate is the inequity of applying the same fee to part time and full time students. This Government spends a lot of time talking about equity, but equity according to what rules? According to what standards? Why should we not have a sliding scale for part time students, who are doing less study than full time students? From the user's viewpoint, it is equity if students pay pro rata for the number of subjects they study. But the Minister refers only to administrative costs. She says-I do not agree with her on this-that because administration costs are about the same for part time and full time students, equity is imposing the same fee on everybody. The students do not accept that. Anybody who has any idea of logic will not accept it either. Quite plainly, as has been stated in this debate, it costs more to enrol a full time student than it does a part time student. There is inequity in that respect. It is interesting to note that, in a Press statement issued by the Minister, she states that education has a very important role in our national development and that this must be maintained. Certainly the Government, in imposing this fee, is not giving any real consideration to national development. The Minister states:
The 1986-87 Budget will allow education to maintain its role of helping secure the long-term development of Australia . . .

The imposition of a fee such as this will not help to encourage people to go to universities or other tertiary institutions. It certainly will not help people from outlying areas in Australia to get a tertiary education. Many young people who want to attend a tertiary institution do not have access at the gate at present, and this has made the situation more difficult.

The focus we need in this nation is to encourage young people to go on with their education. This Government is not doing that. I have just received in the mail from the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations a briefing note on higher education, which states:
Overall, education's share of total budget outlays has declined from 9.0% in 1976-77 under the former Liberal Government to only 7.0% for the coming year.
So in actual fact it has declined quite dramatically. The Federation continues:
Higher education has borne the brunt of these reductions falling from 4.6% of total outlays in 1976-77 to an estimated 3.5% in 1986-87.

There is no way in which this Government can claim that it is maintaining educational standards and opportunity for young people when one looks at those figures. This is particularly sad when one realises that the Government is spending money on many other items which are not of as great significance to national development. The Federation gives an interesting example. It refers to the fact that the America's Cup 1987 defence received $17m in the last financial year, and the current Budget has added another $6.5m. I do not think that that is the right priority for Australia and many young people in Australia do not believe it is the right priority. The Government is prepared to spend $23.5m at this stage on a sporting event when young people are being asked to pay an extra $250 in fees. The Federation continues:

So far its record has shown an inability to even maintain the funding status quo, let alone achieve the injection of funds required to bring these policies to fruition. When will the Government's action begin to match its words?
The Opposition has often spoken on matters of importance and has used exactly the same words: How long will it be before the Australian people find this Government's actions matching its words?

The other problem with the present tertiary education assistance scheme and education benefits is the proverty trap for middle income earners. I illustrate that point by saying that a family in receipt of $30,084 does not get any tertiary education assistance. This means that a family which has a weekly disposable income of approximately $405 gets no assistance to send any of its children to a tertiary institution. This causes considerable hardship for those families. The Government talks about equity. It says that those people are sufficiently well off to make their own way. But when it costs $4,500 to $5,000 to send a student to a tertiary institution, and the family is only earning approximately $30,000, it becomes well nigh impossible.

I will give honourable members the particular example of a family of five in my electorate. The father and mother are well educated. The children are very able students. The father has an after-tax income of approximately $25,000. He has two children who, hopefully, will enter university within the next two years. He says that it will be impossible for him to send his two girls to a tertiary institution because of the poverty trap situation in which he finds himself. He is not eligible for any of the available assistance plans and he simple does not have an extra $10,000 in cash to ensure that his children can go to university. The $250 fee, which is on top of the other costs, is the last straw for him. In the final part of his letter to me he states:

The stupidity of the whole thing is that if I put the first two kids on the dole for a couple of years and then they can go out and TEAS, then it will cost the Government thousands of dollars and it wouldn't really be a fair situation for the taxation system.
In other words, if the children spend two years working, they can receive TEAS and everything will be fine. That is the situation that that family is facing.

The Government has not faced up to its promises on this issue. Young people in Tasmania are very concerned about the implications next year for their tertiary studies. I ask the Government to reconsider the fee it has imposed and to try to remove the poverty traps particularly. I suggest that it should be able to find a way of increasing the upper limit of income at which the scheme cuts out. Maybe the level at which TEAS cuts out should be raised to about $50,000. That might make it possible for people who are in that category and who presently cannot afford to send their children to tertiary institutions to be able to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have an opportunity to make a contribution to the debate on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Australian National University Amendment Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the Maritime College Amendment Bill. The Bills are concerned essentially with the policy decisions that have been made by the Government in a budgetary context with regard to tertiary institutions. I am following the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), to whom I listened most attentively. There were a number of points in his contribution with which I could agree. However, I am disappointed that the opportunity has been taken by members of the Opposition, not just the honourable member for Braddon, to behave with a considerable degree of cynicism, I believe, in relation to this legislation and the general question of the availability, quality and funding of tertiary education in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The request has been made by the honourable member for Braddon and others that this Government should reconsider the imposition of the proposed administration fee of $250. I understand the degree of concern in the community about the imposition of that fee. I do not think it would take very much understanding on the part of people to realise that it was not a decision which this Government, and the supporters of this Government, took with any degree of comfort or enjoyment. I think it has been spelled out very clearly that when the Opposition is returned to government, whenever that may be in the dim, distant future, there is an intention on its part to reintroduce tertiary fees-and not just a $250 a year administrative fee which will be imposed on those people who, by all reasonable measures, could reasonably be expected to be able to meet that fee. Looking at some of the costs involved in providing degrees to students, I think it is estimated, for example, that $100,000 of public sector funds goes to tertiary education institutions in order to provide each medical graduate with a degree. That is a very significant level of investment. It is inappropriate for members of the Opposition to adopt the position they have on this question and to suggest that the $250 a year fee should be withdrawn. All members and supporters of the Government would look forward with a great deal of enthusiasm to an occasion in the future when the $250 administrative fee is withdrawn.

I remind members of the Opposition that tertiary tuition fees were removed by a Labor government. It is all very well for us to hear expressions of concern now about young people going to universities. Too often in the past young people from working class backgrounds, not just from deprived circumstances but from not particularly affluent circumstances, were denied the opportunity to go into the great centres of learning in Australia and other countries as well. It was the intention of Mr Whitlam, his Ministers and his Caucus, in removing tertiary tuition fees to throw open the doors of universities to the sons and daughters of the ordinary people of Australia. The unfortunate reality is that it did not work. However, an attempt was made. It is important to us now and in the future to examine more closely and to investigate the reasons why there is such a serious inequality between effective access to universities, effective access to colleges of advanced education and effective access to higher education generally between various levels of social advantage within the community.

Before I became involved full time in politics I was involved full time, professionally and vocationally, as a teacher. I generally taught in areas which, to a very large extent, were socially deprived, socially disadvantaged. I taught in coal mining, lead mining and rural areas. I started teaching in 1956-30 years ago. Honourable members opposite may be surprised, they may not believe that I--(Quorum formed) I was drawing attention to the fact that, during my period of teaching experience, far too many of the young people who came to the high schools of New South Wales-and presumably the other States as well-because of varying forms of social disadvantage, were not able to proceed to universities, colleges and higher institutes of learning. One of the surprising things is the attitude that has generally been adopted by members of the Opposition. They tend to support the continuation of a situation where opportunities were not made available.

I do not think it is very surprising at all that of, I think, four Rhodes scholars in this chamber three sit on the Government benches. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is a Rhodes scholar, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is a Rhodes scholar and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is a Rhodes scholar. Members have come to this place from various levels of responsibility in tertiary education. My good friend, comrade and colleague the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) is one of the intellectual giants as far as Victoria and this Parliament are concerned. Earlier today we had the benefit of one of his contributions to enlightened economic thinking. We will hear plenty more of that as time proceeds.

In the few remaining minutes that are available to me I draw some comparisons between the concern that has been expressed by members of the Opposition about the $250 administrative charge and what to me is the more important matter of concern in relation to the financial capacity of young people and older people to attend universities and colleges; that is, the availability of the tertiary education assistance scheme. People provide me with a fair amount of evidence to suggest that, because it is not possible for them to manipulate the detail of their adjusted family income-their children miss out on TEAS. They then draw my attention to people who occupy positions and earn incomes in various ways within the community that would indicate that their real income is probably significantly higher than their declared income. SPEECH.PARA: First, I would like to address my remarks to the application of this imposition to students at the Maritime College in Launceston. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) spoke earlier in support of this charge. This problem is becoming particularly acute because of the downturn in our rural industries. Means testing all adult tertiary students on the basis of their own income . . .

Allowing tax concessions for parents' expenditure on text books, stationery, travel and accommodation expenses incurred in the course of their tertiary studies . . .
The third suggestion states:
The payment of a Federal non-repayable living away from home allowance for students forced to live away from home to pursue tertiary studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Education is a right, not a privilege. Last Friday in this House Her Majesty's loyal Opposition was obliged to expose the disgraceful behaviour of the Hawke socialist Government and its betrayal of the elderly, pensioners, beneficiaries, repatriation beneficiaries and widows. Tonight it is my sad duty to expose the disgraceful treatment by the Hawke socialist Government of the youth of Australia and particularly the students of Australia. It must be said that the Hawke socialist Government has shamefully betrayed the youth of Australia, and particularly the students. I have no hesitation in slamming the unprincipled decision of the Hawke socialist Government to impose a $250 tertiary fee from 1987 onwards.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw to the attention of the Parliament and the people of Australia the fact that the coalition, that is, the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, has made no-I repeat no-decision to reintroduce tertiary fees. That was not part of our policy and is not part of our policy now. The Australian Labor Party stands condemned on this issue. It has committed a massive and shameful about-face and no student in Australia will ever believe it again. It is clear that the Federal Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) suffered a major defeat in Cabinet. It is further clear, regrettably, that she no longer has proper ministerial authority over the direction of policy development in her vital portfolio of education.

TALK.START.PARA: —She does not even sign letters to members.

—As the honourable member next to me comments, the Minister no longer even signs letters to members. During the past two years between 9,000 and 14,000 young people, and some old people, have been locked out of the higher education sector as the direct result of the appalling policies of the Hawke socialist Government. It will savagely hit the poor, those from rural areas and those with large families. It is an absolute disgrace. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Education know that.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years ago, in my home State of Tasmania, a motion was put at a meeting of the State Liberal Party Council urging the reintroduction of tertiary fees. It is a matter of historic record and confirmable by my Tasmanian colleagues who are present that I spoke against the reintroduction of tertiary fees. That is not surprising, because back in 1956 when I commenced my law degree at the University of Tasmania and tertiary fees then existed, I campaigned consistently, as a member of the Students Representative Council, as Vice-President of the Law Students Society and as Editor of Togatus, against tertiary fees. In 1956 the fee for a first year law student was #105. Whilst our family has been in Tasmania for a long time, we are not rich. Had I not won a Commonwealth scholarship, of which 100 were then issued in each of the six States, I doubt that I would have been able to go to university and undertake that degree.

One of my best friends, who is a lifelong supporter of the Australian Labor Party, put himself through university without a scholarship. He attended university during the day and drove taxis and worked as a barman during the evening. He then proof read at the Hobart Mercury until 3 a.m., went back home, worked for a couple of hours and snatched about two hours sleep. He graduated in law with honours. I never again want to see people being denied access to tertiary education, where a premium is put on the right to tertiary education. In 1974, as a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the Federal Policy of our Party I opposed a proposal put forward as policy for the Liberal Party to bring in student loans. I will continue to oppose that proposal wherever it raises its head, because I defended young students who were bonded to the Tasmania Education Department and who were sued, pursued and threatened with imprisonment for breaking their bonds. I never again want to see that happen.

It might surprise some people on the Government benches to hear that I feel so strongly on this issue that when the Fraser Government decided to introduce tertiary fees for overseas students-it is a matter of public record-I opposed that decision and I oppose it now. I spoke out against it in public and in this Parliament. I still believe that it is a short-sighted, mean and miserly policy to impose a fee on overseas students. As I said at the time: `Mark my words, this will be the thin end of the wedge'. The Minister for National Development in Singapore took his degree in architecture at the University of Sydney in 1953. He maintains that the degree system in this country which was available to him and his colleagues has done more to build bridges between Australia and its neighbours than has anything else. As a result of the pettiness of the decision, continued by this Government, many of the young people of Singapore, instead of coming to Australia, are going to other places, including the United Kingdom, to take their degrees.

This Government is exposed as having betrayed the young people of Australia. It has betrayed its word. Right through the 1950s and 1960s in relation to the University of Tasmania, the State Branch of the Australian Labor Party, which was then in government, did not take a forefront role in the campaign. It was mainly, as a matter of interest, the Liberal members of the House of Assembly who did so. I wonder how Sir Robert Cosgrove would feel today about what this shameless Government has done. I wonder how he would feel to hear read into Hansard statements which his Party made when in opposition and which now lie in tatters and shreds on the floor. I just remind the House and the people and students of Australia that on 28 October 1981 Senator Ryan said that the Labor Party was totally opposed to tertiary tuition fees. She claimed that tuition fees at any set amount would result in a reduction of access to education. She said that they were the thin end of the wedge and that fees ignored the ability to pay. She then went on:
The Labor Party is totally opposed to the decision . . . to impose tertiary fees . . . we will be opposing generally, and specifically, all such measures.

I was the Minister for the Capital Territory when Senator Ryan said that. I publicly agreed with her. Where do those promises lie now? The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), now the Minister for Trade, was the shadow Minister. At least he spoke out frequently all around Australia, particularly in Western Australia. The Minister is in the chamber. On 21 October 1981 in this Parliament he said:
We--
the Australian Labor Party--
are opposed to the re-establishment of the principle of tertiary tuition fees in general.
The next day he went even further and said:
The Opposition--
that is, the Labor Party, which was then in opposition--
is opposed to the reintroduction of tertiary fees in any form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

We may be prepared to forgive; but the students I have addressed at Melbourne University, the University of Tasmania, the Australian National University and, if I may put in a plug for myself, the students I will address at Flinders University next Tuesday, 28 October, will not forgive, will not forget and will never again believe one word that this Government says.

We will be hit harder than any other State because: First, we are the most decentralised; secondly, we have a higher proportion of large families; and, thirdly, we have a lower income base than any other State. Finally, I leave the House with this thought: How can we possibly believe that the amount will stick at $250? Would anybody believe that? What a joke-$250. TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the overseas students.

—Yes, ask the overseas students, as my colleague so wisely said. Listen to these words: Do honourable members think the Government will hold the fee to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission index of general salaries? What a lot of poppycock. If anybody thinks the Government will stick to $250, if anybody thinks that $250 is the end of the story, they are sadly mistaken. Because we are being curtailed in this debate, because day by day this place becomes more like Moscow and less like Canberra, I have to resume my seat, but I know that out there there are millions of Australians who know that what I have said, what our distinguished shadow Minister, the honourable member for Tangney, has said and what every member of the Opposition has said is right. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have had the delightful task of listening to the points which have been made during this debate and now have the task of responding to some of them. After listening to the last two speakers in this debate, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), both of whom come from the Liberal Party of Australia, both of whom come from Tasmania, one would have thought that they were going to vote against this measure. Of course, we know that they will not vote against this measure.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am voting against it-just you watch.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—In that case we will be looking forward to hearing a call for a division from the honourable member for Denison. The point is that the Liberal Party as a whole, far from having any basic disagreement with us on this policy, is committed to going very much further. It will go further in a highly inequitable way and in a way which will not advance opportunities for young Australians attending tertiary education institutions. During your absence, Mr Deputy Speaker, it was necessary for Madam Speaker to respond to a point of order as to whether this charge was appropriately called an administration charge or whether it should have been called a tertiary fee or a tertiary tuition fee. There is a very simple explanation for that, and that is that the universities and the colleges are totally funded by the Commonwealth Government for their capital expenditure and for their annual running costs, which, of course, are made up of a variety of components, one of which is the cost of administration. This includes the overheads of the purely administrative task of collecting the fees which are already imposed upon students for the purposes of running student facilities, of simply enrolling them and making sure that they are enrolled in the correct course and have a timetable to follow, and of organising the people who teach the courses-all those kinds of things. There is a clear administrative function for which the Commonwealth currently pays.

SPEECH.PARA: We have said that we are not introducing a fee to cover the cost of the tuition of students in universities and colleges, but we do not think it is unreasonable at all to collect a small part of the cost of administering those courses. That is what this charge is all about. That is why it is described as an administration charge. It is not a charge related to tuition; it is a charge which is the same, regardless of the kind of course which students are enrolled in, regardless of the complexity of the course that is being taught; it is related to the pure administrative cost of actually organising the enrolments, organising the courses, providing the timetables and so on for students enrolled in those courses. A clear distinction can be made.

The second point is that the honourable member for Denison, in his usual histrionic, inaccurate and quite besotted way, went on about people having to go back to driving taxis in order to go through university. That will probably always be the case, but it is much less likely to be the case under this Government than it was under our predecessors. We have done the decent thing in providing for living expenses and allowances for students attending universities and colleges, and we have massively upgraded the rates of payments to students enrolled in universities and colleges. Our assistance to students is not based on the same criteria as those which applied to the assistance that the honourable member for Denison crows about receiving when he got a Commonwealth scholarship; it is based on much fairer criteria-the needs of the particular students. Many more poor students are being assisted now with their living expenses whilst attending university and college than was ever the case under any of our predecessor governments.

In the next couple of years we will see a further massive increase in the amount paid to those students who are eligible for student assistance under the Austudy arrangements. We will have the payments to students brought into line with those benefits paid to the unemployed; a policy prescription which has long been advocated by the Opposition spokesman for education, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). He and I see eye to eye precisely on that particular point. He was a little churlish in not commending us for taking that step when we announced it, but never mind, I know that essentially he agrees with what we have done.

We have tried to remove the disincentive that existed previously for young people to remain in the education system because they could receive a higher amount if they were out of the education system and also out of the work force. Our fundamental objective is to see people successfully complete their education to the level they wish and to successfully make the transition to the work force. Of course, not everybody does that. We want to remove the incentive for people to bail out of the education system earlier because of the greater attraction of being out of the education system and also out of the work force and on the unemployment benefit. That has been a massive advance and it has been targeted largely to the poorest people in the community, those people who were eligible for the former tertiary education system scheme, now called Austudy. That is a means tested scheme, which means that we concentrate the assistance on the lower and lower-middle income families or on those independent people whose incomes from other sources are quite low.

It is quite erroneous for the honourable member for Denison, or anyone else who wants to do so, to advance the argument that somehow the imposition of this charge will make it more difficult for poorer people-able nonetheless-to get to university or college. What has been overlooked in that argument is that anybody who is eligible for student assistance, even if it is the smallest amount of assistance, will not be required to pay this fee or charge. To put it another way, when they do pay the fee or charge they will be fully reimbursed for the cost of this administrative charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it be up front or over time?

—It will be at the same time that the charge is required to be paid. The other important point which is overlooked is that, under the circumstances confronting the Government and remembering that the Opposition has been amongst the chorus who have called on the Government to impose fiscal restraint in our expenditure, it has been very difficult to find the additional amounts of money necessary to provide for an expanding number of places in tertiary education. We recognise that it is important, in terms of providing educational opportunities for young people, to see that there is an expanding number of places throughout Australia. But, despite the efforts we have made over the last three years, which have gone some way to making up the deficit which was created during the years of our predecessors, it was not possible in the circumstances of this Budget to find all the funds that we would have liked to to provide additional places. Nevertheless, next year there will be 3,000 new places and one of the reasons that we are able to provide those new places is simply that we have required those who we believe can afford it to pay this small administration charge as a very small contribution to the cost of the administration of universities and colleges.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at it in totality, one sees that this is a very fair arrangement. The poorest students and any student who is eligible for student assistance will not be required to pay this fee or charge. That applies whether they are on Austudy, the Aboriginal study arrangements or the other arrangements of support. Therefore, their access to the education system and to tertiary education will not be prejudiced as a result of the introduction of this fee or charge. What has to be recognised is that there is an enormous number of students--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fee now, is it?
—You are admitting it is a fee?

—I have described at some length why it is an administration charge-because it relates to the cost of providing administrative services to the students. The point is that the majority of students at the moment-and I suspect it will remain so in the future-are in relatively comfortable circumstances. That is simply a result of the way in which our primary and secondary education system is worked. If one looks at the backgrounds of those students who successfully complete the secondary education system, one finds that it is biased substantially in favour of those people who come from higher income families. We have been dedicated to trying to change that, and we have substantially changed that so that now people have a much better opportunity, regardless of the circumstances of their parents, to satisfactorily and successfully complete secondary education. That is really the measure of the equality of access to tertiary education. SPEECH.PARA: There is one other important provision, that is, we are not requiring the whole amount of the charge collected to be handed over to the Commonwealth. Indeed, the institutions can hang on to 10 per cent of it. I think what we ought to be asking the Opposition, particularly the honourable member for Denison, is how he proposes that student assistance be increased and the number of places within universities and colleges be increased at the same time as he is calling for a reduction in taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —By cutting out tax rorts.

—Even when we try to cut out the tax rorts, all we have is a chorus, the most banal contribution to which comes from the honourable member for Denison, in opposition to that action. We have done a lot to cut out the tax rorts, but we do not get any support. In fact, I cannot think of one instance when we have moved to cut out tax rorts that we have had the support of the honourable member for Denison or, for that matter, of many of the other members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Denison can simply not have it both ways. One cannot create positions in universities by magic and one cannot provide additional assistance to students by magic. The money has to come from somewhere. I suspect that the honourable member for Denison has also called for a reduction in the size of the Budget deficit. We are confronted with the task of actually making the arithmetic add up.
—Not for much longer.

—I can assure the honourable member that we will be here for a long, long time. The point is that, confronted with the circumstances which Australia is confronted with at the moment whereby the external situation has required us to impose even greater budgetary restraint than was the case even up to this Budget, we must recognise that for Australia to improve its position in the future will depend very much on our investment in the education system. What has happened is that there have been real increases in the expenditure that we have been committing to the area of education, whether government schools, non-government schools, universities or colleges, because we recognise the simple truth that if Australia is to have a more sophisticated, highly skilled and more appropriately trained work force for the future, we are just going to have to make that kind of investment in our education system. Against that background we hear this wailing and catcalling from the Opposition about this minuscule fee or charge of $250 to recoup a tiny amount of the administrative charge of running our great educational institutions-a charge which is not going to be charged against those students who qualify for student assistance. It is only those people who do not qualify, or whose families do not qualify on their behalf, for assistance under the tertiary student assistance arrangement who are being asked to make contributions to the total costs of running our great universities and colleges.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude with the point that just a little over a year ago, on 21 September 1985, the honourable member for Tangney, the shadow Minister for Education, contributed an article to the Australian, I think it was, the headline of which was `Fees! I am not sure that the honourable member for Denison has read this but, if he has not, I will send him a copy because it contains a very interesting revelation about the views of the honourable member for Tangney on how to fund our tertiary education system. SPEECH.PARA: That opposition in relation to the Australian National University led to one of the most unfortunate experiences we have seen at an Australian university since a former Prime Minister was imposed upon by students at some of our campuses. DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1986, concurrently with order of the day No. 6, the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1986. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now debating the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1986 and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1986. These two overseas students Bills both raise the overseas student charge rates for 1987 and extend liability to new categories of overseas students. Specifically, the principal Bill, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, fixes the overseas students charge rates for 1987 and extends liability, firstly, to diplomatic and consular representatives, their staff and families in tertiary study and, secondly, to overseas students enrolled in secondary education and technical and further education institutions, or TAFE level institutions, which receive Commonwealth funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill imposes a charge of $300 for secondary students and $740 for TAFE students who commence studies in 1987. Students in TAFE who commence their studies prior to 1 January 1987 will pay a lower rate of $530 in 1987. In regard to undergraduate higher education there is a differential application of the overseas student charge as a result of the pressure applied and amendments moved by the Opposition last year when the Government sought to increase by 40 per cent the charge on both continuing and new students. Students who were studying prior to 1986 are now protected by a legislative ceiling of a 15 per cent increase per annum in the applicable overseas student charge. For 1987, the overseas student charge for those students is again increased by the maximum 15 per cent, taking the overseas student charge to 32 per cent of the estimated full average cost of the course. Students who commence their study in Australia in 1986 have no such legislative or regulatory protection, and in 1987 face a 40 per cent increase on the 1986 overseas student charge-specifically, an increase from $3,500 to $4,916 for a standard course, discounted for the $250 tuition fee that we have spent the last several hours debating.

The Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill further extends the overseas student charge liability by removing the current exemption for most overseas postgraduates. The Opposition would like to express two concerns about these Bills. First, we note with serious concern the fears voiced by senior vice-chancellors, directors and principals of colleges of advanced education that the extension of the charge to postgraduate students may reduce the overall research output of universities and colleges. It is sad but true-and I am sure that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who is at the table will endorse this-that it is often difficult to get Australian postgraduate students to conduct postgraduate research in Australia. It is often the case that many overseas students visiting Australia and gaining their education in this country go on, especially in the sciences and technologies, to conduct research which is very beneficial, of course, to them and their home countries, but essentially to Australia. The concern has been expressed by vice-chancellors, directors and principals of colleges of advanced education that the extension of the overseas student charge to classes and categories of postgraduate students may hamper and put paid to the very important research work that many of those students undertake. We on this side of the House hope that in future the Government will closely monitor the effect of the extension of the overseas student charge in respect of that postgraduate research effort.

Secondly, we repeat the concerns we voiced last year that arbitrary increases in the charge of the order of 40 per cent annually are extraordinarily punitive on existing students and a discouragement to potential new students. I note, pointedly, that in respect of existing students the Government has seen fit to raise the overseas student charge to the maximum, to the ceiling that was legislated for by an Opposition amendment last year when we debated this charge. Importantly, the point I am now making is that the charge is increased by 40 per cent for new students. Many overseas students who have based their calculations on an expectation of their costs throughout their period in Australia are already in Australia undertaking secondary education. For them their education is a continuum in terms of their stay in Australia. We fully recognise that they are making the jump from secondary schooling to higher education and we recognise the Government's right to impose and indeed to increase an overseas student charge in respect of higher education. However, the fundamental point I want to make-we made it last year and we will continue to make it although we will not move an amendment on this occasion-is that the Government has some responsibility to provide for overseas students in Australia some certainty and predictability in respect of the overseas student charge for which they are likely to be liable.

Our concerns about students discontinuing their study and our concerns about some overseas students in secondary education in Australia deciding not to go on to higher education in Australia seem to be confirmed by Budget Paper No. 1 which notes on page 101 that there will be `a reduction in the aggregate number of overseas students in Australia in 1987'. I think that, in part, the increases in the overseas student charge have something to do with that expected reduction. To further buttress that point, the Opposition strongly believes in the concept of the Commonwealth having a tacit contract with overseas students, the concept of the Commonwealth being a party with overseas students to a contract which extends from their arrival in Australia to the completion of their courses of study in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contracts have escalation clauses.

—If the honourable member is patient he will see that I am making a point which I am sure he will understand and accept. We believe that one of the Commonwealth's obligations under this contract is the provision of certainty and stability with respect to the costs faced by overseas students. We do not deny-the honourable member would understand this very clearly from his Foreign Affairs experience-the Government's right or any government's right to increase an overseas student charge. However, we believe, concomitant with that government's right, is the importance of the host government-irrespective of whether it is the Australian Labor Party or the Liberal and National parties-extending to visitors in Australia who come here to undertake secondary or higher education study some certainty and some sense of future security so that, as their parents budget in their home countries and as they budget while they are here in the host country, they can have some understanding of what they might be up for in future years. That is the reason why last year we moved an amendment seeking to place a ceiling of 15 per cent on increases in charges for existing students. We call on the Government to listen to what we say in respect of this matter. We are not making a partisan political point. We recognise the absolute fundamental importance from a foreign affairs perspective and from a foreign aid perspective of extending educational opportunities in Australia to the children of our nearest neighbours, but in making such an extension do we not also have a right and a responsibility to extend to our guests some certainty and some predictability as to the extent of the overseas student charge for which they may be liable? For the honourable member who made an appropriate point by way of interjection, that is the point I make.

SPEECH.PARA: The increases in the overseas student charge for students who commenced higher education studies in 1986 are a special case and that is why we do not move an amendment this year. We recognise that last year the Government signalled its intention to move to 45 per cent recovery in 1987, hence the 40 per cent overseas student increase for those students. I hope that the Government will recognise that the points we make are valid, that the contribution we make in this debate is a responsible one and that we have not charged off contrary to what we said last year and moved an amendment on this point. Nevertheless, to summarise, we put forward the argument that we believe there is a central imperative to restore certainty and predictability to the overseas students program. It is time to ease the anxiety caused by unpredictability and the fear of unannounced increases which upset all measures of tight financial budgeting by overseas students.

On this point let me stress my own bona fides in this debate. I do not make a partisan political point and I do not seek to make political advantage out of an issue which is centrally important to all parties in this Parliament. If we are to extend an important form of foreign aid to the children of our near neighbours it is ludicrous that we also preside over deportations, anguish and anxiety, as happened in recent months when students who were not apprised of and certainly not aware of the overseas student charge when they left their own country have come to Australia and now find themselves unable to pay it. To preside over a situation which sees our popular Press blazoned with headlines about student A or student B being arrested with a view to deportation is not what our aid program in this area should be all about. I fully recognise the Government's right for budgetary reasons, for responsible economic reasons and for reasons central to the overseas student program to gradually increase the fee, but we are talking about an element of predictability and an element of certainty. I think it entirely reasonable that the Government should voluntarily limit itself to a reasonable increase, and the reasonable increase which we suggested and which was passed last year by way of amendment was a ceiling of 15 per cent.

It is time we not only let overseas students know the costs for tomorrow but also, as I have said, provided a sensible range of predictable increases. Last year the Government accepted the rationale in accepting a maximum 15 per cent annual increase in the overseas student charge. The amendment was passed in the Senate and the Government, of its own volition, brought it back to the House of Representatives and accepted it. So the points I make are not foreign to the Government and they are not ones that the Government has hitherto shown itself unwilling to accept or agree with. As I have said, the Government accepted this rationale last year in accepting a maximum 15 per cent annual increase in the overseas student charge applying to students who had commenced studies prior to 1986. It put the 1986-87 students on notice by telling them that the charge would be raised to 45 per cent recovery in 1987. The Government told the students that last year and that is why we do not break faith in what I am saying and move an amendment this year. The point I now make is that it is reasonable, with the exception of the extraordinary increases imposed by the Government in 1986-87, that there be a fair and average increase in the future. I seek the approval of the Minister for Science, who is at the table, to incorporate in Hansard a clear, straightforward table showing the overseas student charge rates and percentage increases from 1980 to 1987.

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) Higher education students who were studying prior to 1986 or TAFE students studying prior to 1987.
