TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and the House. If I have made an error in my compilation of the table and if the Minister would like to correct it in the course of debate, I would welcome that. The point is not to convey information that is wrong; the point is not to convey information that is misleading; the point is to convey information, and when one looks at the table one sees that it conveys clearly, notwithstanding any minor changes, that there has been a relatively reasonable and sensible increase in the overseas student charge year after year. In 1982 it went up 13 per cent; in 1983, 9 per cent; in 1984, 16 per cent; and in 1985, 16 per cent. In respect of new students for 1986-87 there has been a large increase of 40 per cent, whereas in respect of continuing students it has been limited to 15 per cent because of the amendment moved by the Opposition and accepted by the Government. That is simply the point I make. I restate without embarrassment that many new overseas students arrive in Australia having carefully budgeted for the cost of their courses. Their parents and families often make great sacrifices, and the students are left in both their home countries and in Australia with very little room for financial manoeuvring. We believe that if the Government continues in future years to increase the fee markedly, many students will be seriously disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time left to me-I am sure the Government Whip will be pleased to know that I will not take up my full allocation-I would like to say a few words in general about the overseas student program. I indicated in the debate last year that the Opposition was inclined towards the entrepreneurial educational philosophy reflected in the report of the Jackson Review of the Australian Overseas Aid Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—In our view, that report correctly stated, and I welcome the support of the honourable member for Kingston, that the Australian education system can compete and should complete for international student enrolment in the global education market-place. The honourable member for Kingston may despair as to the success he has enjoyed or not enjoyed so far. However, to give him his due, the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) understands the export industry and the potential Australia has in terms of attracting overseas students. It is against that background that I make these remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the Jackson committee's report on overseas students. Without prejudice and without exciting all sorts of hysteria from some members on the Government side, might I say that in embracing, dare I say it, a market-based approach to the overseas student program, the Opposition would wish to gear higher education for a major expansion in this area. Quite simply, our singular goal is to build an education system which rivals the best in the word and which promotes choice, excellence and achievement in all spheres of activity, both for our own students and for the students of overseas countries. Education can be, must be and, we believe if the right decisions are made, will be, a major source of foreign income through services trade. If we are worried about our current account deficit and balance of trade situation, it is madness for some staff associations and some academic communities at particular institutions around Australia to be blinkered in their approach to the opportunities that exist for them and our nation in respect of attracting overseas students. I know that there is a measure of bipartisan agreement on this matter in this chamber and elsewhere.

There is significant untapped demand for higher education throughout the Asia-Pacific region. We see Australian institutions playing an increasingly dominant role in training and educating the young people of this region, both on a developmental aid basis and on a commercial basis. These students are already showing their willingness to travel to the United Kingdom, Western Europe and the United States of America. We offer a country which is much more proximate to their own countries, we offer an attractive climate, and increasingly we offer a changing culture which is more akin to that which they might find in their home countries. We are all on the threshold, if we take the right decisions in respect of higher education, of a vast export industry which will benefit not just our overseas neighbours but certainly ourselves. As I have said, it will assist in the reduction of our balance of payment difficulties by bringing in much needed export income. It will also help maintain Australia's cultural and political influence in the Asia-Pacific region, and it will run parallel to wider foreign policy and cultural exchange programs. On that point, while I do not have much personal foreign affairs experience, unlike the honourable member for Kingston and others, I had an interesting talk to the honour- able member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) the other day. In a very important first hand anecdotal way, he spoke about the incalculable benefits that exist for Australia in extending this sort of opportunity in terms of both aid and commerce. One cannot put a dollars and cents value on the future national benefit that can be derived from an Australian Foreign Minister travelling to our nearest neighbours and dealing with the movers and shakers and political leaders who obtained their education in Australia. It is in that context that I make these remarks.

The potential is only now being realised, but the estimates of the education foreign earnings, the employment potential and the foreign affairs ramifications of which I have just spoken are in fact breathtaking. The Opposition agrees with the Jackson Committee that the overseas student charge, provided there is certainty for those already enrolled, should be raised progressively so that by the mid-1990s overseas students not on scholarships would be paying the full cost of their education in Australia. We further believe that the charge should be paid directly to the institutions which the overseas students attend. The hidden subsidy now being provided by Australian taxpayers to subsidise overseas students partially or fully, which totals now over $100m a year, would be made explicit and used to fund scholarships for several thousand other overseas students.

Just let me briefly flesh out that point. We believe that in time, from the educational perspective and from the perspective of the higher education institutions in Australia, the partly subsidised and fully subsidised overseas students should be progressively phased out so that all overseas students in their relationship with institutions are full fee paying students. Instead, through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, the Foreign Affairs Department and the Foreign Affairs vote we should extend, in whatever number we wish to fund, full scholarships or part scholarships to potential overseas students studying in Australia. This would be a much tidier situation than exists at the moment. The educational aspect would be separated out from the foreign affairs aspect. We would fund Australia's overseas students through ADAB and through Foreign Affairs. We could extend to them full scholarships or part scholarships, which would enable them to pay fully or partially the fee that Australian institutions would charge to fee paying overseas students.

In our view, the proposal I have just outlined has been sensitively designed to free up progressively and consequently restructure one important aspect of Australia's most regulated conservative and protection-bound industry-the education industry. Its adoption would allow overseas students unlimited access to tertiary institutions in Australia without prejudice to Australian students and with viable scholarships so that Australia's aid contribution to the educational enrichment of its less developed neighbours would be made explicit.

It is worth noting-and this is my final comment-that while overseas students have two bites at the cherry as a result of the Government's decision last year to allow institutions for the first time free rein in enrolling overseas students on a full fee paying basis, it continues to be a cause of distress to the Opposition that Australian students are denied this opportunity. We recognise the inability of Australian taxpayers to fund unlimited numbers of domestic students, let alone overseas students, but we think it is scandalous that there remains a major internal contradiction in the Government's education policy which requires urgent attention-that is, that the same full fee paying opportunities extended to overseas students also be given to our own.

In conclusion, the Opposition does not seek to amend these Bills. We do, however, make the point, as we have done time and time again, that the Government should look to its own decisions with a view to extending predictability and certainty to overseas students coming into Australia. If in the future we take the right decisions, Government and Opposition alike, the Australian education industry can be a major source of export income providing benefits to ourselves and certainly providing benefits to the overseas students and the countries from which they come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) said when he commented that when people come to Australia to study they are entitled to know their future financial obligations. Australia is also entitled to charge for the education of overseas students other than those assisted under our overseas programs. In fact we could go further and, as the honourable member for Tangney said, we could market it-we could make education an export industry. The case of the Goulburn college for seniors came to mind when the honourable member was speaking. Senior citizens were pouring into Australia to do subjects at the Goulburn College of Advanced Education-courses such as computing and psychology, which some of them chose to apply themselves to rather than subjects such as basket making and doll house construction. I know that the college for seniors had to limit its overseas numbers so that Australians could find places in its courses.

SPEECH.PARA: If a country member can judge on the basis of the letters received, I would say that charging overseas students for education at universities and other tertiary institutions is popular in the electorate, but not always for the best of reasons. Australians, ever conscious of belt tightening-which everyone is asked to do-find it difficult to understand why taxpayers should tighten their belts a little further to educate overseas students. That is an argument which is fair enough when those students can afford to pay, but it does ignore an attitude which it is important that we develop in the interests of foreign relations, trade and security in the zone in which we live. Appreciation of Australia by countries in our region has been enhanced by our acceptance of overseas students, and this will continue. Over 1,200 full time students are currently accepted and their fees are paid by our Government for their secondary and tertiary education. They return trained to their countries and my view is that the dividend for Australia is great. Countries that benefit appreciate the assistance and governments express that appreciation with closer relations and trade benefits. Good relations mean less hostility, which is a factor in our own national security.

The training of many young people in Australia at Australia's expense has brought to leadership in the source countries people who feel a strong kinship with our country. This must strengthen our links with them, including our trading links. That policy will continue, but it does not mean that we ought to allow other overseas students, those who select Australia as their place of study, to come at great public expense. Very often those students can afford an education in their own countries and when all sections of the community find Treasury's arms short and their pockets deep, as is now the case, we ought to be charging overseas students who come to Australia unassisted programs at least some of the fees.

The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill vary the categories of students exempt from the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979. Australian scholarship winners, where the rate is at least $3,500 per annum, who commence study before 1 January 1987, are exempt. The Bills allow recoupment of the cost of supporting places for overseas students at our educational institutions and place a charge liability on diplomatic and consular representatives, staff and dependants who undertake tertiary courses. A student who commenced a course after 1 January 1986 will contribute to 45 per cent of the full average cost of a place. A student who commenced a course before 1 January 1986 will incur a charge of 32 per cent of the full average cost.

Along with the honourable member for Tangney, I believe we need to support these Bills. I believe this legislation is a realistic assessment of Australia's economic position and also our relations with our overseas friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to participate in this debate because, as honourable members will know, I have had an interest for some time in the question of overseas students in Australia. The charges imposed in this legislation will have an impact upon students and I think it is important that we continue to monitor the nature of that impact and that we understand it. I commend the very comprehensive and excellent speech made by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) in relation to this matter. I will emphasise two of the points he made and, for the sake of brevity, will refer largely to his comments, but in a complementary way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill fixes the charges to be made for new students enrolling in the 1987 academic year. As was mentioned by the honourable member, the fees paid by those students-I mention particularly those students who are now in schools in Australia and who would be likely to enrol next year in universities-will be 40 per cent higher than those that they would have paid if they were entering university this year. The uncertainty and the disadvantage that those students will suffer as a result of the size of those increased fees are such that they are likely, in my view, significantly to damage Australia's reputation. Honourable members have emphasised the question of certainty. I think Australia's reputation is such that we ought to be very conscious of the impact of any variations in relation to these fees, and we ought to be conscious of variations of the order of 40 per cent and the likely impact that will have upon the way in which Australia is viewed.

The second point made by the honourable member for Tangney which I want to reinforce was the impact of this legislation imposing charges on postgraduate students. I represent this Parliament as a member of the Council of the Australian National University. On Friday a fortnight ago I sat through a Council meeting where this matter was raised. I think it incumbent upon me to report to the Parliament that the university is very concerned at the impact of these charges upon post-graduate students, particularly those who are in receipt of awards provided by the Australian National University itself. Honourable members ought to under- stand that the imposition of these charges upon those students who receive a very modest stipend as post-graduate award holders is such that they will probably lose one-half of the value of the award that is given to them. Honourable members can imagine that if they receive an award and the amount is halved by a charge that is imposed, it is not very likely that they will be encouraged to enrol at that institution.

We went through the rolls of Australian National University students who received awards last year and a large number of the students who received post-graduate awards were from overseas. The university is relying upon those post-graduate students to undertake very important work in the Institute of Advanced Studies. I think honourable members ought to know that that program of advanced study, which is so important to the reputation of the Australian National University, will, in the view of the Council, be put at risk as a result of the imposition of these charges. The Council itself does not want to be seen to be criticising governments. But that was the nature of the information that was conveyed to the Council members as they sat around that table.

Australia's overseas student program is very important for Australia and its reputation. The students who come to Australia can be ambassadors for us when they return to their countries, or they can be our constant critics. A nexus between Australia and the students who have studied here is established. If their experience has been good, the nexus is desirable. If their experience has been bad, that can do Australia very considerable harm. I do not want to allude to national leaders who have panned Australia in the Press. I just ask honourable members to think about some of them who have had a go at us from time to time and ask why that has happened. In relation to one prominent Asian leader, it has often been suggested that this attitude to Australia was formed by an unsatisfactory association with us. It may not have been as a student, but his attitude is certainly a result of an unsatisfactory association or relationship with Australia.

The way in which students are being impacted upon as a result of this legislation and the changes that have been made over time means that many students will go away with a view of Australia that will not help us in the future. Recently I read a paper which was prepared by students and which I thought was very persuasive. They made the point that we do not take into account the beneficial effects that these students have when they come to Australia. How many of us think of the program in terms of the balance of payments and how much money students bring to Australia when they come or how much their parents send them to help keep them while they are studying? It is not just a question of the cash that will go into the Government's coffers; there is also the money that comes to Australia by way of transfer payments when we have a successful program bringing students to study in Australia. The impact is very considerable.

The second matter that the students mentioned, in addition to the ambassadorial relationship, was that of contracts and so on. We know from anecdotal evidence that many students have advantaged Australia and Australian contractors when in positions of responsibility in their home country, in government or in business. They may be able to influence the granting of contracts, have had a background of Australia and experience of Australians, for example as engineers or architects, and have confidence in us and what we are about.

The imposition of the fee, which is to increase by 15 per cent this year for students who are already enrolled, has been commented on by the honourable member for Tangney. We acquiesced in the charge being increased by 15 per cent this year when the Government presented the regulations required under the legislation as amended on the last occasion. I repeat my understanding of the circumstances in which that amendment was negotiated and settled with the Government. I understood that it was settled in a form not that would impose mandatory 15 per cent per annum increase every year from now on but rather that would enable increases to be imposed that would accurately reflect the costs to Australia as a result of changes in the consumer price index. The reason the increase was not fixed to the CPI was that the Government said to the Opposition in the discussions: `There may well be currency variations that will require some greater or lesser change than the change in the CPI, and we need some flexibility'. That is the basis on which the 15 per cent increase was settled. If the Government insists on increasing the rate by 15 per cent each year, let it understand that I for one will watch for regulations coming forward to give effect to a 15 per cent increase and I will look very seriously at whether the regulations ought to be disallowed. Whether I will have the support of my colleagues is another matter, but certainly that is my view.

I encourage the Government also to look at the way in which some students have been treated this year. Students have produced a number of papers about the hardship that has been imposed upon them. I will not go into any detail as to the nature of the hardship that has been imposed; but in many cases it has been considerable. Students have suggested that there be an improvement in the administrative arrangements. One of the suggestions they have made is that domestically the Government should improve the arrangements by providing for instalment payments of these charges. I encourage the Government to look at that suggestion.

I also encourage the Government to look at the administrative arrangements outside Australia. One matter which has been brought to my attention and which is a very serious indictment of this Government is the way in which the administrative arrangements, particularly for Malaysia, occurred, especially in the establishment of quotas and the selection of students. People who observed the process from the outside could not be satisfied that the system of selection was fair. We saw Press reports in Malaysian papers, particularly, day after day, that did Australia very considerable harm. Some were headed: `On ``raw deal'' ', `Still in a bind', `Probe' and `Quota has been filled'. I could cite paper after paper in which students were reported as saying that they were getting a raw deal in Australia.

I made representations for a student who I thought had been treated poorly. I wrote to the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in some detail about that student's case because it seemed to me that the student had been treated very unjustly. I put before the Minister information from the Principal of Taylor's College in Malaysia, from which a number of students who have been able to come to Australia have matriculated in the past. I was able to put before the Minister a letter from the Principal of that college which I thought was very informative and which outlined the way students saw the Australian rules on this matter. I will not go on at length because I am being pressed to conclude my remarks. I understand that. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) needs 15 minutes to reply. I simply want to record that I am not the only person saying these things. When I wrote to the Minister for Education about this matter I was given certain information. I will comment adversely, too, on the fact that I did not receive the information from the Minister herself. That matter ought to be of very real concern in this House.
I having raised the problem that students were not being selected on the basis of academic attainment, but on a whole lot of other factors as well, the reply from the Minister's office said:

The Overseas Student Office was unable to approve entry to all students who obtained place offers and, in allocating the available places to Malaysian students, had to take into account the timing of offers by institutions, whether students were sponsored by the Malaysian Government and whether they received offers to courses nominated to the Overseas Student Office, as well as the level of their academic results. There was some resentment on the part of applicants who were unsuccessful after all these factors were taken into account, particularly if they were aware that some students with lower matriculation scores had obtained entry. Unfortunately, it was not possible to satisfy all the applicants for study in Australia.

That is a masterpiece of understatement. There was enormous resentment from students at the way in which they were selected, and the fact that when students in the same institution got quite different results the student with the lower results was successful in obtaining entry into Australian academic institutions does us no credit whatsoever. The fact that the Minister, through her proxies, acknowledges that does not help.
The final matter that I wish to mention relates to the way in which representations are dealt with by this Minister for Education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister ever seen the letter, by the way?

—I do not know whether the Minister has seen the letter, because the letter to me in response to representations that I was making on behalf of a constituent who was a friend and relative of Miss Agnes Yong Mei Kwan of Kuala Lumpur was signed by Sarah Portway. I do not know Sarah Portway, but she is said to be a private secretary. I have an acknowledgment in relation to that matter signed by Mary O'Neill, a ministerial liaison officer. TALK.START.PARA: —As would be obvious to the House and anybody listening, today is education day in the House of Representatives. We now move to the seventh Bill being debated today, specifically the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986. This Bill establishes the legislative framework for the introduction of what the Government has entitled Austudy, the single education assistance scheme, which from 1 January 1987 will replace the tertiary education assistance scheme, the secondary assistance scheme and the adult secondary education assistance scheme, with a full year cost of $528.5m, assisting some 238,000 students. The legislative changes are fairly minor as the administrative provisions, the determination of applicable rates and the eligibility criteria will all be detailed in the voluminous regulations to be made under the amended legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the Bill currently before the House does three things. Firstly, it widens the definition of `student' beyond tertiary student, allowing secondary students to be treated as students within the purpose of the broader Austudy education assistance scheme now being introduced and debated. Currently the legislation is limited, by definition, to tertiary students. Secondly, the incidentals allowance of up to $100 a year currently paid to TEAS and ASEAS recipients is to be abolished, although the Government assures us that it has been absorbed into the living allowance payments. Thirdly, the Bill provides certain transitional arrangements and tightens up some provisions concerning the interaction between welfare payments and education assistance. Previous arrangements have permitted an element of double dipping between, for example, unemployment benefits and TEAS. The Opposition supports the move to reduce the opportunity for such abuse of assistance measures.

In amending the principal Student Assistance Act to provide for the granting of assistance to both secondary and tertiary students, the legislation improves the current arrangements under which the secondary assistance scheme and the adult secondary education assistance scheme have had no legislative basis. Both of these schemes have been administered only by ministerial guidelines, despite their significant financial impact. The Austudy scheme, which this legislation will facilitate, is therefore in some ways a significant advance on previous arrangements. However, it is a cause of considerable concern on several grounds, with which I will deal in the course of my speech.

The Opposition welcomes moves to remove the financial disincentive to study. The wider availability of unemployment benefits and the significant unemployment benefits available at all age levels, when compared with the applicable rate of education assistance, according to some studies has encouraged some young Australians to discontinue their studies for the easy option of cash in hand. In other words, they have preferred to follow the money. Certainly the financial weighting in favour of the unemployment benefit has, at the secondary level especially, not served to encourage higher levels of retention and participation in years 11 and 12.

While welcoming this decision to set a common rate of education assistance and unemployment benefit, I note with displeasure, however, the wrong statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) that the disincentive to study `was a legacy of the years of Liberal and National Party government from 1975 to 1983'. It should not be forgotten that the former Liberal-National Party Government initiated the first two investigations which recommended parity between unemployment benefits and education assistance, namely, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission `Learning and Earning-A Study of Education and Employment Opportunities for Young People' report and the Beswick study of tertiary students finance. Moreover, the Labor Government increased substantially the gap between TEAS and unemployment benefits in the 1983-84 Budget to something in the order of $16 a week. This was despite election rhetoric and assurances that Labor would immediately align education assistance and unemployment benefits. It will be six years from the 1983 election before Labor will completely deliver the goods-six years to make a simple adjustment. So let us have none of these attempts at political trivialisation of this issue by the Minister for Education.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, there was a disparity when we left office, but it was increased by this Government in 1984. Most honourable members will remember also that the Opposition's 1984 policy on education pledged to bring together the rates for unemployment benefits and education allowances. There is a bipartisan agreement that the financial disincentive to study resulting from the fact that unemployment benefits are set at a higher rate ought to be removed so that involvement in education or training is actively encouraged through such income support schemes. There has persisted for many years now a perverse incentive for some students, at secondary level especially, to abandon their education and take advantage of the availability of unemployment benefits at sufficiently higher rates, rather than continue their studies and accept a lower rate of educational benefit. To some extent this disincentive to study merely accelerated the trend in the early 1980s for many young Australians leaving school immediately after completing the compulsory years of education. The availability of unemployment benefits is not the only reason why young people at the margin of education-those who do not want to go on to undertake higher education and those who do not perceive any additional personal benefit they would gain from completing years 11 and 12-choose to discontinue study. It is not the only reason, but certainly it is a factor.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to use some of the time available to me tonight to speak to some of the wider issues of youth income support and education. First, however, let me return to my opening remark that the Austudy scheme has some elements which are cause for considerable concern on the part of the Opposition. We express two principal concerns about the operation of the Austudy scheme for secondary students. Firstly, we believe the major change from activity based to age related assistance will cause considerable problems and may not be the most effective way of promoting involvement in education. Secondly, we believe that the change in the method of payment of Austudy from the parent or legal guardian to the student directly could be counterproductive or misguided. One of the problems in targeting education assistance in Australia is that our State education systems differ so markedly in important areas. Some States commence compulsory education at younger ages than others. Compulsory education, therefore, ends in certain States at younger ages.

The question of basing secondary student assistance on activity or on age is by no means an easy one. We recognise that it is a vexed question. A fine line exists between basing assistance programs on involvement in years 11 and 12 or on the age of the young person, taking into account the easy availability of unemployment benefits from age 16 onwards. There are just as many reports, papers and studies to support either option. The Opposition believes, however, that the Government has, on balance, opted for the less beneficial alternative. Austudy, with an age related benefit payable directly to the student from age 16, is flawed in several respects as a result. The principal aim of education assistance should be to promote greater participation in post-compulsory education by easing the financial burdens faced by families with children at years 11 and 12. In these years, the costs of education escalate dramatically. But more importantly, it is in these senior secondary years that a supportive family network is most essential in making the decision to remain at school.

All of us accept that young people are exercising independent judgment much earlier. They make critical decisions affecting career and life potential, sometimes from age 14-for example, in choosing subjects from the ever-diminishing core curriculum. They demand recognition of their independence and their maturity and it is essential that governments and the wider community embrace sensitively and with understanding the significant independent decision-making capabilities of our young people. However, there are important decisions such as whether to continue in education beyond year 10 in which the student's family will greatly assist in the making of the final decision. To clarify this, a student can drop out of school and seek work without the agreement or support of his or her parents, but it is very rare indeed for a student to continue in education without the agreement, commitment and financial support of his or her parents. The decision to leave school can be made independently but not the decision to continue in secondary study. That requires family financial and moral support.

In deciding to move away from the principles which have guided the secondary assistance scheme-namely, an activity-based payment directed to the families of year 11 and year 12 students-the Opposition believes that the Government has taken a great gamble with the motivations affecting continuing education. The abandoning of activity-based assistance for years 11 and 12 towards the age related benefit from age 16 will vary in its effects between States as a result of the institutional differences affecting age in years 11 and 12. The number of 15-year-old students who would have been eligible for the means tested student assistance scheme allowance next year will now be denied education assistance in year 11 or, in limited exceptional cases, in year 12.

In many situations the families of those students are even now working the figures to see whether their family income can be stretched any further to support their year 11 children until they become eligible for Austudy when they turn 16 years. It is instructive to look at the State differences in the educational participation of the 15-year-old cohorts. In Victoria, of all year 11 students, only 2 1/2 per cent are still 15 years of age. In the Australian Capital Territory the figure is 3 per cent; in New South Wales, 4 per cent; and in Tasmania, 9 per cent. Yet in the Northern Territory the corresponding figure is 36 per cent; in Queensland and Western Australia, 43 per cent; and in South Australia it is 45 per cent. Against the background of these percentages there will be situations in which some families will be unable to support their 15-year-old children in year 11. They will most likely try every avenue to save the money elsewhere, whether by cutting back on discretionary expenditure, on clothing, or even in some harsh cases cutting back on the basic family budget. But in the most acute cases it is foreseeable that these 15-year-old students will have to abandon their education. The parents will have to say to the son or daughter: `In the light of these Government changes we simply cannot afford to keep you at school'.

To be scrupulously fair, I note that the Minister for Education conceded this possibility last Thursday in the other place. She has indicated that the Government will be very closely monitoring what happens to 15-year-olds who go into year 11 and who have to wait some time before becoming eligible for Austudy. I can assure the Minister that the Opposition on this occasion, although it has fallen short of proposing an amendment to change this situation, will also be closely monitoring the situation. If there is time I will come back later to the Minister's justification that since 15-year-olds are ineligible for unemployment benefit there is no need to ensure eligibility at that age for Austudy. However, I must say that I found that logic a little odd.

I move to the second concern I raise with the payment of Austudy; that is, the payment of benefits direct to students. As I mentioned earlier, the financial support mechanisms for a student in secondary education are not simply an individual student responsibility but primarily a family responsibility. The Opposition believes we should encourage families to meet their responsibilities. One of the essential reasons why the secondary allowance scheme was introduced was to assist low income families to support their children in years 11 and 12. Paying Austudy direct to students, as the Government wishes to do, will have several serious consequences. It is not hard to envisage-one has only to look at one's own children, let alone children in one's electorate-some students pocketing the Austudy benefit, in which case it will not directly assist his or her education or the overall family income. It is not hard to perceive this education assistance payment ending up, in some exceptional cases, in pinball machines or being consumed in cigarettes or in other undesirable consumption. Moreover, taking into account the influence of the family in determining whether a young person stays on through years 11 and 12, it is vital to encourage the family to support the promotion of education as a high ideal.

If we are talking about participation rates, we still have a big job to do within the Australian community, especially in Labor electorates. I make a specific socio-economic point: We have a big job to do to convince parents that higher education-years 11 and 12 and even beyond-is important for the future of their children. The best way to do this from the Government's perspective, apart from occupying the moral high ground, is effectively to target education assistance, to pay it to the families to give financial support and buttressing to those ideals. The Minister for Education has explained that the Austudy benefit, if paid direct to parents, would be taxed and therefore would have a diminished valued. We respond that this need be the case only where the Government decides to include education assistance as a form of taxable income, and it need not. Family allowances are not taxed and there is no reason why this specific family oriented, family directed education allowance also cannot be tax free.

In the Senate last Thursday the Opposition moved an amendment to the legislation to direct the Austudy benefit for secondary students to the parents or to the legal guardian and to retain the operation of this benefit in line with the replaced secondary assistance scheme. We would like to record our profound disappointment that the Australian Democrats in the other place chose not to support that eminently sensible and rational move. I give notice that in the Committee consideration of this legislation I will move that same amendment. I would encourage the Government to look at it again with a view to ensuring that if we are spending taxpayers' money to encourage higher participation in secondary education we ensure that it is spent and directed in the right and proper way and that is by paying it to the parents or legal guardians of students.

I now turn to a couple of the wider issues of youth income support. The principal point I wish to make is that, whilst the common rates for Austudy and unemployment benefit are welcome, this move alone will not remove disincentives altogether. Let us recognise that the chief difference between education assistance and unemployment benefit is this: Student allowances are means tested against family or parental income; unemployment benefit is not. Moreover, student allowances are means tested, as I have said, on parental income as well as the income of the recipients; unemployment benefits are not. Tertiary students are still subject to extremely tight and restrictive income tests, while unemployment benefits are potentially available to the sons and daughters of even millionaires. There is a high degree of injustice in this approach, although we recognise that the solutions are extremely problematic and elusive.

One option that must be considered is the Beswick partial dependence formula, which would treat an under 18-year-old student as wholly dependent on parents but then reduce the parental dependence factor by 25 per cent a year until the student is classed as 100 per cent financially independent at 21 years of age. Under this plan different income tests would apply to the parental and student incomes for each year of age. Although I am personally attracted to such an approach, as it recognises better the transition during tertiary education from dependent young adult to independent adult status, there are still the common problems of drawing arbitrary categories based on aggregations and assumptions which leave little room for flexibility.

There will always be cases which do not fall into the easy categories designed by public policy experts. There will always be people at the margin. Nonetheless, there are students in genuine need. The classic case, for example, is the 18-year-old student whose parents take no responsibility for his or her education or welfare. Under present arrangements the student is regarded as dependent on parental support and is therefore ineligible for Austudy. I have recognised in my remarks that these inequities are problematic and complex, but they need to be faced up to. If we are ever going to remove all disincentives to study we must face up to them very shortly. The wide availability of non-means-tested unemployment benefits will continue to be a factor in encouraging some students, particularly those in genuine need whose parents incomes disqualifies them from Austudy, to choose cash in the hand rather than study under acute financial pressure.

I have long remembered Senator Chaney's remarks, made after many years as Minister for Social Security. He found that people follow the money. If we are going to extend assistance benefits to people in recognised need we have to ensure that the incentives are put in place and that they not be perverse incentives which would encourage behaviour we would not wish to support or recognise. The rationalisation of youth income support schemes which this Government has initiated, to its credit-I recognise that-has been long overdue. Past public policy decisions, sometimes to meet temporary needs on a trial basis, led to 37 different schemes for different aspects of youth experience. The Opposition and I applaud the Government for tackling some of the contradictions between these schemes and moving towards a simpler regime of income support for young Australians.

Because the hour is late and because one or two other members wish to speak, let me leave my remarks about the wider question of income support for young Australians and the need to continue the reform that this Government has initiated, a reform that we support, and reaffirm two of the remarks I have made about this legislation. We are concerned about the shift from Austudy support being paid to year 11 and year 12 students to students who reach the age of 16. We hold back from moving an amendment now. We note that the Minister has recognised that there are doubts about this change. In the Senate last week she said that she of all people would be closely examining the effects of this change. Let me repeat: We will join her in examining those effects with a view to supporting and suggesting improvements if improvements need to be made. Finally, I foreshadow that during the Committee stage of this debate we will be moving an amendment to restore and preserve the situation whereby financial assistance is extended to the parents or the legal guardians of students still at high school.
Debate (on motion by Mr Maher) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week we have heard of the $90m of taxpayers' money that the Hawke Government is spending on advertising, public relations and research for its own party political purposes. The latest abuse is the $2m plus spent in an attempt to convince the electorate that the fringe benefits tax is not an additional tax burden. I say $2m plus because chances are that the Australian Taxation Office will rule that this expenditure is a fringe benefit for the Australian Labor Party and new taxes will need to be imposed on ordinary workers to meet this tax on a tax. The list of abuses of public funding goes on. Funding is provided through the Australia Council for unions, including the deregistered Builders Labourers Federation, and for artists and muralists in residence so that they can deface our urban environment with graffiti. Millions more dollars are spent through the Theatre Board, the Community Arts Board and the Literature Board, not on ballet, music or literature, but on left wing homosexual groups and even terrorist organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight, however, I wish to concentrate my remarks on another example of irresponsible funding, the funding through the community employment program of Streetwise comics. These comics, which I have with me, are developed by the Redfern Legal Centre and the New South Wales Law Foundation. The Doctors Reform Society has even promoted Streetwise comics in its journal, The New Doctor, devoting a full page to a message from a Mr Michael Ward who works for the New South Wales Department of Health and is promoting these comics. Let us look at a message these comics bring to our young people. They assume throughout that the police are brutal and dishonest. Parents get all the blame for the problems of their children. No parent is ever depicted as loving his or her children. There is only a desire to take revenge on his or her child. Car stealing is shown as a value-free pastime. The comics are all anti-police, anti-parent and anti-authority in their bias.

In the two comics I have with me police are drawn as pigs. Traditional authority and figures such as parents, private doctors, police and even the community youth support scheme and the Youth Affairs Council staff are depicted as apathetic, unsympathetic and hostile. We must not consider these Streetwise comics in isolation, but rather as part of a burgeoning juggernaut of government sponsored networking organisations seeking to alter traditional society according to their minority ideological outlook and special class interests. Many of their activities undoubtedly give community activists the warm inner glow of moral satisfaction, if not superiority, as well as paid employment with our taxes. They will, however, increase instead of decrease the burden on the disadvantaged. They will increase the alienation of the genuinely disadvantaged, ensuring that they stay that way and that other youths who might have led normal lives also end up on the wrong track.

Some of the advice offered by the Streetwise comics under the guise of informing children of their rights is anti-social. For example, the comics inform young people that children can leave home at the age of 16; that they can buy alcohol at 18; that girls can have sex at 16; and that boys can have homosexual sex at 18. According to these Streetwise comics, they are free to choose their own gods at any age but unfortunately they need their parents' consent to obtain an abortion if they are under 14.

The Doctors Reform Society journal, under the misnomer `Health for Youth', depicts a situation entitled `Doing it'. The scene goes something like this: Two young people are going steady and Tim asks Maria whether she will do it with him. The ensuing dialogue, with the girl protesting that he must take responsibility for any child and Tim's emphatic refusal, brings them to the decision that the pill is the answer. Maria's fears of being thought a slut for using the pill are brushed aside with the comment: `I don't think people who go on the pill are sluts, they have common sense'.

These comics are insulting to many of our professional people and are totally negative. They are targeted at poorly educated young people with a lack of knowledge who need assistance in a positive manner, and an appropriate attitude should be adopted to ensure that their rights are upheld. These comics are socially destructive, yet they have the backing of our Federal Government under the guise of an employment grant. So many of our people today are living in poverty; pensions are being reduced; our hospitals are in crisis; education funds are being cut; and students are being penalised. I simply ask: Where are the Government's priorities if it is not prepared to stop this abuse of public funds and the moral destruction of our youth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express appreciation tonight for a major project, in which Amatil Limited is involved, in connection with the bicentenary celebrations. I express a special appreciation to that company. Amatil, of course, is a leading company in tobacco products, beverages, poultry, snack foods, communications and packaging. It is a joint sponsor, with the Australian Council of National Trusts, of a very major project associated with the bicentennial celebrations called `A Gift to the Nation'. `A Gift to the Nation' is a commitment to the responsible preservation of Australia's heritage. Individually, each of the projects within the bicentennial program is a vital component of our historical, environmental and cultural heritage. Collectively, these projects represent the largest community-based heritage program ever undertaken in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Amatil's sponsorship comprises the magnificent amount of $1.6m. That will enable the National Trust to undertake the restoration of 13 projects around the country at a total cost of more than $5m. The sponsorship is the largest yet provided by a corporation to a cultural organisation in Australia, and it signifies the concern shared by both Amatil and the National Trust in providing tangible benefits for future Australian generations. In connection with this project, the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, stated:

The support and involvement of Amatil Limited as sole national sponsor of A GIFT TO THE NATION marks a great step forward in heritage conservation in Australia, splendidly encouraging for the Trust movement. The sponsorship, totalling $1.6 million, is the largest of its kind in Australia and represents a major commitment by Amatil to our Bicentennial celebrations.
The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in commenting about this project, stated:

Australia's Bicentenary in 1988 will be a rare moment in history to consider our national heritage and to ensure awareness, understanding and enjoyment of that heritage by future generations of Australians.

The work of the National Trust and Amatil-with the support of various Commonwealth, State and Territory Government Departments and local organisations-will result in the permanent preservation of some of Australia's most significant heritage sites.

A whole range of those sites is identified in this brochure that I have with me. They include, for example, Juniper Hall, in Oxford Street, Paddington, Sydney-a magnificent building that dates back to 1824 and is the earliest surviving domestic building east of the city of Sydney. The fact that Amatil, together with the National Trust, is prepared to commit funds of that kind to ensure that such buildings will be not only restored but will be preserved and maintained-important elements in the heritage inheritance of Australia for all future Australians-reflects very great credit on it.

The 13 projects range from individual restoration efforts of that kind to the Callington Mill in Oatlands in Tasmania. That mill dates back to 1837 and was once the major flour mill for the region. Other buildings are Labassa, Manor Grove, Caulfield; Old Government House, George Street, Brisbane; Wolston House, Grindle Road, Wacol; Vienna, Hunters Hill, Sydney; the Old Melbourne Gaol, Russell Street, Melbourne; Hartley Street School, Alice Springs; Cooma Cottage, Yass; and so on. There are a number of others, including the Norman Lindsay Gallery at Falconbridge in the Blue Mountains. As I have said, this is a great contribution by Amatil. It is actively involved in my area. It recently bought out Steggles Pty Ltd, the chicken company. Steggles advertises itself by saying that chicken is the best meat and Steggles have the best chicken. I think that the concern for Australia's heritage shown by Amatil reflects very great continuing credit on it. I congratulate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year when I spoke on the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs I mentioned my concern that Australia had reduced significantly over time its support for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I have been concerned, and continue to be concerned, about the priorities of a government that is able to find money for organisations in the international arena that are less worthy, yet, in relation to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the amount of money that is available for the very important humanitarian tasks that that organisation is carrying out, seems to be reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I was therefore surprised when the Government, through the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), issued on 10 October this year a Press release which would indicate that there had been a significant change of attitude on the Government's part. You might not be surprised, Madam Speaker, that I question whether there has been such a change. I simply record that the Minister announced that another $400,000 had been found for three special programs to be undertaken in the Indo-China region: An amount of $220,000 was found for an anti-piracy program. I certainly would not complain about that. An amount of $80,000 had been found for a screening program to assist the Lao people who might want to return to Laos. Sixty-one people had accepted to return to Laos under that program. An amount of $100,000 was set aside for the UNHCR to expand its project at Kompong Chhang in Cambodia. That program started in 1980 and, again, is designed to help returnees.

I mention those matters because, quite frankly, I want to compare them with a far greater issue of concern in relation to refugees in that area and to ask what the Government intends to do about it. I note that a number of petitions have been tabled over the last few weeks dealing with a matter which has been of very considerable concern to me. One that I found most recently was tabled by your deputy, Madam Speaker, but there have been others. I will read it:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, shows the Thai Government recently announced that Khao-I-Dang refugee camp will be closed on 31st December 1986. More than 25,000 Cambodian refugees who survived the ``Killing Fields'' of the Khmer Rouge and entered Thailand after 1979 are still resident in Khao-I-Dang, We hold grave fears for the future and safety of these refugees who will be relocated to camps along the Thai-Cambodian border when Khao-I-Dang is closed.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will uphold its enviable humanitarian record and act with all haste to facilitate the acceptance and resettlement of as many of these refugees as possible, including a proportion of those who have no relatives to sponsor them.

I have attended meetings with Khmer people and with Laotian people. I can only say that there is a very real and genuine concern amongst many of those people as to what is likely to happen. The refugees in Khao-I-Dang, I am told, at the moment number 25,728. There may be some people who, as displaced people, arrived after 26 August 1984 and are not available for resettlement, who might be included in that area. I know they are considered illegal and might be sent back to the border area. But there are 25,728 souls who have not found a place anywhere else and whose future is very much at risk. I regard this as a very important question. I endorse the concerns of the Khmer and Laotian communities. I note that they have written to Ministers seeking information as to what Australia is doing not only in terms of trying to change the Thai Government's attitude on the closure of the camp but also asking what we might be able to do particularly to help the Khmer. We have done a great deal of work amongst the Vietnamese people and the boat people but there is a concern that the Khmer people particularly should be given some assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise an issue that affects part of my electorate, and that is the need for mosquito eradication in the Homebush Bay area. I raise this matter tonight because the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government have worked together to nominate Homebush Bay as a bicentennial park for Sydney and an amount of $8m has been made available. A significant problem in this area, which is being exacerbated by the creation of the park, is that of mosquitos. It has been drawn to my attention by the State member for Ryde, Garry McIlwaine, a Labor member who lives in Concord West, who has written to me about this matter to try to get Federal government instrumentalities along the Parramatta River to spray for mosquito eradication. SPEECH.PARA: Last week a resident was reported in a local newspaper as complaining that she could not with impunity hang her washing on the line. Every time she went out to hang her washing out she was bitten savagely by mosquitos. On Saturday night I was sitting next to Mrs Kane from Homebush at a dinner. She said that the problem is very serious, although it had improved. She told me that some years ago, when her son was small, she had put him outside in the sun and in one hour he had had 54 mosquito bites. That was six years ago, but the situation has improved.

This year, being a very wet year, long grass is creating even more problems in the area. I am basically an environmentalist and I know that the mosquito larvae are essential for the small fish in the mangroves and that Homebush Bay is the last stand of mangroves left on the Parramatta River. There are all sorts of ecological balances and attractions for fish and birds in trying to revitalise the area.

The area has been traversed by gas mains and Water Board sewers and there are many problems. An enormous amount of work is going on in the area and we trust that, in the fullness of time, when the millions of dollars that have been generously made available have been used and the park is a show place for Sydney, the mosquito problem will be turned to. If we are spending all this money on creating a bicentennial park in the middle of Sydney we cannot have the place infested with mosquitos. I am drawing this matter to the attention of Parliament mainly on behalf of the residents of parts of Homebush between Parramatta Road and Homebush Bay and those residents of Concord West who live near Homebush Bay. Mosquitos are annoying people this year. As I said earlier, the matter was brought to my attention by Mr McIlwaine, by residents and from Press reports. TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday in the House the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) made a ministerial statement in relation to anti-terrorist measures at airports around Australia. SPEECH.PARA: I cannot for the life of me see why anybody would legally want to import tear-gas for a proper purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —The New Right.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the International Law Commission last meet.

(2) Did Australia or any other member make proposals at the last meeting of the Commission for a multilateral agreement on the topic of Relations between States and International Organisations which might be more acceptable than the 1975 Vienna Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. The International Law Commission last met from 5 May to 26 July 1986.

2. The topic of Relations between States and International Organizations has been considered by the International Law Commission in two parts. Draft articles on the status, privileges and immunities of the representatives of States to international organizations were prepared by the International Law Commission in 1971 and referred to a diplomatic conference which in 1975 adopted the Vienna Convention on the Representation of States in their Relations with International Organizations of a Universal Character. Many provisions of this Convention considered to be unbalanced in their treatment of the interests of host countries of the major international organizations, and no such host country has become party to the Convention, which has not entered into force.

Following the adoption of this Convention the International Law Commission ceased to give attention to the subject matter of the Convention and no proposals have been made in the Commission to develop the basis of a new convention on the same subject. The International Law Commission is now working on the other part of the topic, namely the status, privileges and immunities of international organizations, their officials, experts and other persons engaged in their activities who are not representatives of States. There has been no significant progress in the preparation of draft articles, which have not been given priority by the Commission in the light of the limited interest shown in the topic by Governments.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated saving in expenditure to his Department as a result of the overpayments project for (a) 1985-86 and (b) 1986-87 in each category of benefit or pension and how are these amounts determined.
(2) What (a) was the cost of the overpayments project for each benefit in 1985-86 and (b) what is the expected cost in 1986-87 and how was this cost determined.
(3) What assumptions underlie the allocation of fixed costs.
(4) What was the total cost of the overpayments project for 1985-86 and what is the estimated cost for 1986-87.
(5) What are the costs of the major components of the overpayments project for 1985/86 and 1986/87 and what are any variations due to.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) The following table sets out the estimated savings by benefit type for 1986-87.
$m
Age Pension ... 4.7
Invalid Pension ... 3.1
Widow's Pension ... 4.2
Supporting Parent's Benefit ... 4.0
Unemployment Benefit ... 10.7
The corresponding total figure for 1985-86 was estimated to be $13.1m.

These savings estimates are based on the improvements in the department's overpayment performance which have been and will be achieved as a result of initiatives taken within the Overpayments Project. The figures outlined above do not include savings relating to the Social Security Amnesty which translate into a full year equivalent of almost $20m.
